TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Pornography
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth: That we the undersigned, having great concern that Canberra is now the `Porn Capital' of Australia and because of the spread of moral pollution in our nation, call upon the Federal Government to introduce immediate legislation in support of existing State Legislation:

1. To provide strict controls over the importation, production, sale, hire or mailing of video-cassettes particularly in the A.C.T., with the open sale and/or hire of only G, PG, and M-rated video cassettes; and the total prohibition of the sale or hire of R rated video-cassettes, so that R rated films can only be viewed in an adult theatre by persons over 18 years. We totally reject the concept of `X' rated or `N.V.E.' rated video-cassettes, which would allow the legal sale and hire of hard-core pornographic videos for viewing in the homes of our nation, which would endanger our children; and
2. To give whole-hearted supported to Senator Walters's Private Member's Bill to implement the recommendations of the Select Committee on Videos; and

3. To dramatically improve the Federal Attorney-General's Guidelines for Classification of Video tapes/discs, which restrict the importation, production, sale or hire, screening in private homes and especially mailing by Australia Post, so as to include the total prohibition of any pornographic, obscene or blasphemous video cassette, or film which exploits or degrades women as sex objects, or which contain child pornography, bestiality, sodomy, group sex or violent sex acts with women, such as rape and pack rape, sadism and torture, etc., or which promotes homosexuality or lesbianism;
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will protect our society, especially women and children from moral pollution and its harmful effects,
And your petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Constitution: Reform
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the leader and members of the Senate of Australia: the petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully shows that there has been clear demonstration of public dissatisfaction with the mismanagement of the Victorian Otway forests, and we pray that: the constitution of Australia be reformed to recognise significant expressions of public concern, eg petitions, by the formation of a committee to represent public requests.

PETITION.TITLE: Violent Television Programs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth, that:
We are concerned about the increase in violent television programmes for children and particularly those programmes promoting violent toys that are available for sale in Australia.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you support the Broadcasting (Prohibition of Violent Programmes for Children) Act 1988 which has been presented by W.A. Independent Senator for Nuclear Disarmament, Jo Vallentine. This Act aims to prohibit the broadcasting of children's TV programmes that are violent and that promote toys modelled on characters, weapons or other war accessories which are also available for sale in Australia.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Beahan (from 14 citizens), Hill (from 38 citizens) and Sanders (from 21 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Home Ownership
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth, that:
Recent huge rises in mortgage interest rates have pushed the cost of buying their own home beyond the reach of most Australian families.

Those Australians already paying off home mortgages are now suffering severely and unfairly through increased mortgage payments or longer repayment times so that many will never pay off their mortgage and go further and further into debt unless interest rates fall substantially.

Now, therefore, your petitioners request that the Senate in Parliament assembled require the Hawke-Keating government to cease its excessive reliance on high interest rates as its major economic policy weapon and instead to use other measures which would allow interest rates to return to levels that do not force most Australian home-seekers out of the housing market-and many Australians out of their homes-so that the traditional right of home ownership is returned to average Australian families.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Messner (from 17 citizens) and Sanders (from 92 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Disaster Relief Funds: Queensland
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth, that:

We are concerned that the National Party in Queensland is diverting money given by the Federal Government to the Queensland Government to alleviate natural disasters; that it might not be finding its way to its intended targets; and that it is being diverted to the coffers of the National Party itself or otherwise to expansion projects promoted by members or supporters of the National Party.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray the Federal Government be asked to legislate for an audit of account from the Queensland Government for every dollar or cent provided by the Federal Government for any type of relief operation in Queensland.

PETITION.TITLE: Housing: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That we consider the current level of interest rates on home mortgages to be intolerable:

2. That we believe that Senator Haines' Income Tax Assessment (Housing Loan Interest) Amendment Bill 1989, which provides for tax relief for mortgage payers and is currently before the Senate, provides reasonable relief to the current unacceptable situation;
3. That the Senate assembled should, therefore, urgently debate and pass Senator Haines' Bill;
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament; the humble petition of the undersigned showeth: That Kingsford-Smith Airport is becoming increasingly congested and existing facilities are inadequate to handle the number of aircraft or their passengers.

The Federal Government's plans to divert aircraft from Mascot to Bankstown and/or increase landing charges for peak periods will do little to relieve congestion and will place enormous financial and other burdens on commuter airlines and their passengers.
We therefore call on the Federal Government to take heed of airline and travel industry warnings and-
1. give immediate approval for the construction of a third runway at Mascot
2. upgrade existing radar and other traffic control facilities to enable Australia's high safety record to be maintained.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Health Insurance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Senate assembled in Parliament: The petition of certain citizens of Australia, draws to the attention of the Senate that the Government is about to introduce into the Senate, legislation changing health insurance. These changes will increase the cost of health insurance to members of employee based funds and will do nothing to help the elderly, as is being claimed. Big public funds will increase their surpluses by taking money from more efficient funds. People will be forced back onto Medicare, which will not help to maintain private health insurance.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate reject this legislation.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament. This petition of the below citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate that we support the continued cover for all abortions on the Medicare schedule. We oppose any attempt to restrict access to the rebate to under Medicare.

Medicare cannot pretend to be a Universal health care system without providing a rebate for a termination of pregnancy. Those who will be hardest hit by proposals to restrict access to items 6469, 274 and 275 on the Medicare schedule are poorer and disadvantaged women who will not be able to meet the cost of a non-subsidised abortion.
Your petitioners humbly pray and request that the Senate will vote against any attempt to restrict access to abortion or any abortion-related items on the Medicare schedule.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Robert Ray (from 73 citizens) and Schacht (from 113 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Community Services and Health Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the President and members of the Senate assembled: We, the undersigned medical students and medical practitioners of Australia, oppose changes to general medical practice contained in the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1989. We believe:

All Australians should have equal access to our health care system and that there should not be two tiers of medical insurance rebates for general practice and we reject the concept of a vocational register for general practitioners.
Undergraduate training in general practice should be upgraded and that ongoing medical education should continue to be controlled independently by the profession.
The mechanism for establishing the vocational register proposed in the legislation violates the ethics of the medical profession as embodied in the Declaration of Geneva, and is totally unacceptable.

We pray that the proposed changes to general medical practice contained in the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1989 should be rejected outright by the Senate and that it should be replaced with a broadly based consultative process to address the problems within general medical practice and general practitioners training.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Chaney (from seven citizens) and Patterson (from 611 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and the senators in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That every abortion kills an unborn human baby.
That the right to life of all humans is the most fundamental and essential of all human rights.
That the Government's first duty is to protect this right to life.
That the most defenceless and threatened lives are those of unborn babies for whom the Government is duty bound to take extra steps to protect.
That in 1987/88 taxpayers funds through Medicare provided Medical Benefits for 61,879 abortions totalling $6.4 million.
That in the same year Commonwealth grants to the States indirectly financed the deliberate killing of thousands of other unborn babies in State Public Hospitals.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will carry out its duty to protect the right to life of Australian babies by ceasing to fund abortions through Medicare, restricting grants to the States and by all other means at its disposal.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Burns (from 831 citizens) and Colston (from 934 citizens).

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FINANCE AND PUBLIC ADMINISTRATION

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Coates)-by leave-proposed:

That the time for the presentation of the report of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration on the Aboriginal Development Commission Annual Report 1987-88 be extended to 29 September 1989.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition does not oppose the motion which has been moved by Senator Coates. It is our understanding that there is still further work to be done on that report and we regard the inquiry which the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration is undertaking as an important one. However, I want to speak on this motion because I think it would have been desirable if this report could have been available in time for the debate which the Senate will shortly undertake on the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission legislation and other legislation affecting the administration of Aboriginal affairs.

SPEECH.PARA: I would just like to remind the Senate that at the time this reference was sent off to the Committee, it was pointed out that there were some rather odd features of the report and some rather odd omissions from it. No doubt the Committee will be doing its best to obtain an explanation for those omissions for the edification and information of the Senate. However, since that reference we have seen nothing to reduce our concern about the administration of Aboriginal affairs. Only yesterday Warwick Smith, the Opposition shadow Minister for Aboriginal affairs, released a draft Cabinet submission which had been provided to him and which relates to the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC). I take this opportunity to say to the Government that I trust that it will not use its financial power over the ADC to anticipate the eventual outcome of the legislation before the Senate.

What is proposed in this draft Cabinet submission is a series of options which would involve using the appropriation power effectively to deprive the Aboriginal Development Commission of its functions. While it may be due to the legislative process that will occur at the end of the day, it is not a process which, in the view of the Opposition, should occur using this underhand administrative and financial tool. I seek leave to table the press release issued by Mr Smith yesterday and the attachment, which is a draft Cabinet submission. That submission makes it quite clear that currently, within the bureaucracy, if not within the Government, the means that could be adopted to short-circuit the legislative process are being canvassed.

The Aboriginal Development Commission was established after an extensive legislative process in which this Senate was prominently involved. It involved the introduction of draft legislation which was then extensively discussed with the Aboriginal community, using as the source of communication a working party of public servants, not politicians. I believe it was a thoroughly successful consultative exercise. It resulted in a substantial number of amendments to the legislation after Aboriginal input had been received. In the view of the Opposition, the Government is pursuing a course without the support of the Aboriginal community, after a Clayton's form of consultation which the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration has indicated did not leave the Aboriginal people with the understanding that the Bill would proceed without further consultation with them. The public evidence of the consideration of the undermining of the whole legislative process, which is contained in this draft Cabinet submission, should be of concern to all senators and, indeed, all members of the House of Representatives.

On what is a busy afternoon, I do not wish to prolong the debate, but I trust that the Government will not use the Budget to make the debate which we will be having over the next couple of weeks about the future direction of the administration of Aboriginal affairs in this country a nullity and a farce. If the Government chooses, prior to obtaining the legislative sanction of the Parliament, to denude the ADC of all resources other than the internal resources generated by it, largely because of the grants made through the previous Government, I think that would be a real abuse of the legislative process and the process of government.

I ask Ministers who are present to consider the implications of this matter: I would have thought that, when he was in opposition at least, a Minister like Senator Evans would have been concerned at this subversion of the process. I hope that in Cabinet, Ministers have defended due process and made sure that this technique is not used to undermine the Aboriginal Development Commission further. I seek leave to continue my remarks.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is leave granted to table the press release?

—Mr President, Senator Chaney is seeking leave to continue his remarks, but this is a motion which really ought to be carried today because the report was due to be tabled today. I have sought leave for an extension of time to table it.
—I do not seek leave. I am sorry, I do not wish that to be postponed.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. I refer to the enormous disruption in terms of personal inconvenience and cost inflicted on Australians by the refusal of domestic airline pilots to abide by a direction of the Industrial Relations Commission. In view of this, the threat of further action by the pilots and the clearly stated intention of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) to accept the result of the national wage case only if it succeeds in getting all it wants, does the Government now accept the need for effective procedures to ensure enforcement of Commission decisions to replace the existing provisions which, two years ago, Mr Willis said had fallen into disrepute and were moribund?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chaney has asked his question in the context of the current airline pilots dispute. The Government deplores the recent rolling strike action by domestic aircraft pilots which contravenes directives from the Industrial Relations Commission. The Government is committed to the centralised wage system at present and it would like to see the airline pilots dispute resolved within this system. That system has both rights and obligations for those within it. If the pilots refuse to abide by their obligations within the centralised system, then the Government would support any application for the cancellation or suspension of existing pilots awards and agreements. This would cancel all the rights and protections that are provided to them by the centralised system. If the pilots choose to go outside the system, then the Government will fully support any action by the airlines to bring the dispute to an early end.

ANSWER.PARA: As far as the Government is concerned the matter concerning the airlines is quite straightforward-either the pilots accept the obligations of the award system that entitles them to its rights or they forfeit those rights. I think that principle is generally true across the industrial relations system. It is a slight touch of licence for Senator Chaney to say that the ACTU has said that it will walk outside the system if it does not get all it wants. Only this morning-I think this is correct-the ACTU wages committee accepted the principles enunciated in the decision of the national wage Bench. That will now be progressed through the system in accordance with the restructuring principles.

In answer to the two specific points which Senator Chaney made I make those comments. In the context of those comments it is not necessary for me to consider the other part of the question which has been the burden of Senator Chaney's public argument recently-that is, that the Commission should be empowered to enforce its decisions in particular ways. That course has been followed in Australia before without much success. I do not see that there is any reason, when we have had a comparatively successful series of wage outcomes over recent years--

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!
—Comparatively with Senator Stone's time-that it would be necessary to introduce that system now.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Will the Minister inform the Senate of the amount of Commonwealth financial assistance and incentives provided to Sarich Technologies Ltd (STL), the orbital engine company, or to any other individual or organisation that is involved with the development, planning and production of the new Sarich two-stroke engine in Australia? Further, in the knowledge that the Minister would be aware of the much publicised agreement between STL and the State of Michigan, United States of America, to provide certain funds and infrastructure support towards the construction of a plant to produce the engines in that State, is he aware of any United States of America Federal government funds or incentives being directed towards this project? Finally, has the Minister or the Government in any way obstructed or hindered the Western Australian Government from matching or increasing the pledges of the Government of the American State of Michigan to this project?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased that Senator McKiernan asked this question, because there has been a great degree of misinformation, particularly in Western Australia, about the Sarich Technologies Ltd engine and the move to manufacture it in the United States in the State of Michigan. As a senator from Western Australia, the questioner knows full well that there has been a lot of misinformation, some of which I would like to correct. First of all, in terms of Commonwealth assistance of a broad nature-that is to say, Commonwealth assistance which is applicable across industry-the following grants have been received by the Orbital Engine Co., or Sarich Technologies Ltd: under the industry research and development program, $4.8m for developmental work on the engine; under the export market development grants scheme, $800,000-over a period of years; and under the demonstration grants scheme-from governments of both political persuasions, Liberal and Labor-$200,000. The company has a carry forward benefit of $5.7m under the 150 per cent tax concession scheme and the Government financed up to $0.25m for a commercial feasibility study of the Sarich engine.

ANSWER.PARA: A substantial amount of further support from a range of existing Commonwealth and State government programs would have been available if the projects had proceeded to the manufacturing stage in Australia. For example, $15.25m would have been accessible under the motor vehicles and components development grants scheme. There have of course been further approaches from Mr Sarich and others to the Government for additional assistance. On the basis of assessment of the Sarich engine made by the Government and the Australian Industry Development Corporation and confirmed by the Sarich Orbital Engine Co., it is quite clear that manufacture of the engine would have been viable in Australia but the return on investment in Michigan would be somewhat larger and marginally more attractive than for manufacture at home in Australia.

The Government has participated in feasibility studies and in a major program of financial advisory work. Recently, a high level interdepartmental committee was established to advise on the alleged cost disability and whether external economic benefits warranted special government action. This sort of special attention to single projects is unusual, however potentially significant, and it is not common for the Government at Commonwealth level to take this sort of action.

I refer to the suggestion which has been made that the Commonwealth Government took no interest in this program. I have mentioned the financial incentives which were made available under the general incentives programs which are available to all industries. Quite apart from that, there were suggestions that Ministers and the Prime Minister and others took no interest in the developments at Sarich Technologies. I note that between 1987 and 1989 the Prime Minister and I both visited Sarich Technologies, as did two members of my staff, seven officers of my Department at various times and the Director of the Automotive Industry Authority, Mr Sexton. There were also visits by an officer of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, an officer of the Treasury and an officer of the Department of Finance. These visits all took place in the last 18 months or so.

I put those matters of fact on the record because I am, to say the least, somewhat disappointed by some of the comment and misinformation which is being distributed, particularly in Western Australia. I remind the Senate that it is only six or seven weeks since Mr Sarich came to see me personally and advised me that he would probably establish this engine plant in Michigan. The specific purpose of his visit was to ask me, if I can use a colloquial expression, not to bag his decision to take that plant to Michigan. That was the specific purpose of his visit to me. Since his return from Michigan I cannot say that, honouring as I did the spirit of that request from Mr Sarich, perhaps naively, I have been treated with any equity in this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you going to make up for lost time?

—I am only putting facts on the record, nothing else-no comment. I must say here that we admire the technology, we admire Mr Sarich's inventiveness and, of course, we wish him well in his venture in Michigan. I also add that, in addition to Mr Sarich, so members of the Western Australian Government have had things to say about this enterprise. In terms of consideration of industry policy issues and what moneys should be made available to particular firms, this Government does not need the advice of politicians in the Western Australian Government. We do not need that at all. Those who were the architects of Western Australia Inc. are not well placed to advise the Commonwealth Government what it should do about this issue. I do not for a moment share Senator Chaney's description of Western Australian Government Ministers as a bunch of thugs. They are a compassionate, sensitive, likeable group of people, but on this particular issue they have not proved to be particularly right.

ANSWER.PARA: The question really extends to how much governments should be involved in putting taxpayers' money into enterprises of a particular kind, picking one out in favour of another. I said earlier in the course of my response that the Federal Government made available to Mr Sarich some $11m over a number of years and made an offer of a further $16m or $17m and that those offers were added to by very generous offers made by State governments. But the offers the Federal Government made to Mr Sarich were made as part of industry granting systems of universal application; that is, not specific to any particular firm or company. If we do not accept that principle, we run into the question of what happens if we choose Mr Sarich and somebody else whom we do not choose proves to be equally successful, an argument which is usually characterised as an argument about picking winners.

As a general principle, this Government will not be part of the process of picking one firm over another. I will just illustrate the point. Only two weeks ago I had the pleasure of opening a Comalco plant at Bell Bay which has received no specific government assistance. It is a highly competitive international plant, entirely for export. It has been developed by the good work of the Comalco company in terms of both research and development and marketing.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to what could only be described as the dire circumstances facing Tasmanian missionary Miss Jackie Hamill, a member of the Christian City Church, who has been taken hostage by rioting prisoners at a Philippines military gaol on Mindanao Island. Has the Minister received a report from the consular officer who, I understand, was sent to the area yesterday and is in contact with the negotiating team? Is it true that media reports in which it is claimed that Miss Hamill has been singled out for execution by the prisoners are incorrect? As the deadline for the commencement of executions or the provision of a bus has only been extended until 5 p.m. Australian time, can the Minister please advise whether he anticipates any resolution of the problem within that time frame? In the light of the fact that the situation involves an obviously innocent Australian citizen, has the Government offered the Philippines Government the advice of trained Australian military or police negotiating specialists?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I may be able to answer some of those questions. The Australian citizen is caught up in a very distressing circumstance. It occurred when Ms Hamill and her companions, members of the Joyful Assembly of God, were conducting a service at the metropolitan district command detention centre in the Philippines city of Davao. The prisoners holding the hostages demanded one bus, to be provided by 3 o'clock yesterday, to go to an undisclosed location with the hostages. This deadline has been extended by 24 hours. The prisoners holding the hostages have threatened the lives of those hostages if their demands are not met but have not singled out Ms Hamill specifically. The hostages involved are Ms Hamill and seven Filipinos, and the prisoners in question number some 15. The negotiations are continuing.

ANSWER.PARA: Since my brief was written I have had some rather confused reports over the wire service, supplemented very briefly by a report from a consular official just a few minutes ago, suggesting that some hostages have escaped. I am not clear but I think that Ms Hamill is not among those who have escaped. There is a report that Ms Hamill has a slight facial wound but is not seriously hurt. I am sorry that my answer sounds a bit disjointed but I do not have all the details. One or more remaining prisoners are still holding hostages. The authorities have sent in the mother of the main prisoner involved to negotiate with him, so there is some hope or expectation that some sanity will prevail in this very difficult situation. I will report further to individual honourable senators with an interest in this matter as soon as the situation becomes clearer. Yesterday we sent a consular official to Davao, and that official is in contact with the Philippines Government negotiating team. Obviously everything that can be done will be done on behalf of the Australian caught up in this situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a supplementary question, Mr President. In the last part of my question I asked the Minister whether the Government has offered the Philippines Government the advice of any trained Australian military or police negotiating specialists.
—I am not able to answer that question. I do not believe so, but that is something we will bear in mind depending on how the situation develops over the next little while.

—My question is to the Minister for Finance. I refer to various estimates made of tonight's Budget surplus. Can the Minister for Finance confirm the accuracy of an estimate by a company called Access Economics of a 1989 Budget surplus of a stunning $11.15 billion?
—Are we going to get a preview?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, you are not. Of course, I will not be giving any indication of what the Budget estimates are. They will be announced in about five hours' time. When they have been announced people will be able to make their own judgments about the accuracy of the Access Economics forecast published last week and, having done that, will be able to make their judgments about how well qualified Access Economics is to undertake further financial evaluation on behalf of the Liberal Party and whether Access Economics is likely to be any better than the people who compiled the Liberal Party's shadow election Budget in 1987. We will then know whether Mr Peacock has hitched his wagon to a star or whether the star is on the wane. I note that Senator Stone had some positive things to say last Friday about some of his old Treasury colleagues when he was asked about the Treasurer's critical comments on Mr Peacock's taxation proposals, which the Treasurer delivered in a speech, I think, on 9 or 10 August. This was on 2UE, when Senator Stone was broadcast saying:

ANSWER.PARA: Again, you know, Mr Keating has access to, you know, very large resources, departmental resources, in his own department, the Treasury, and also the Australian Taxation Office, and I'd be the last person-having been in charge of the Treasury for a few years-I'd be the last person to knock the professional competence of those bodies. They are extremely competent. Having said that, I also want to make it clear that we will-we are in the process of getting our own numbers put together.
People can put their own interpretation on that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. I preface my question by congratulating the Minister on his stand taken on the Channel 10 Face to Face program on Sunday 30 July, that he would fight to protect the South Alligator River in the World Heritage listed Kakadu National Park. Obviously, the Minister is well cognisant of his powers under section 9 of the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act 1983. Will he give an undertaking that if Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd (BHP) deems the exploration stage of the Coronation Hill mine to be successful and indicates its intention to go ahead with the mine, he will declare the South Alligator River to be endangered and will take action similar to that taken in respect of the Franklin River in Tasmania? Secondly, of course, the Minister will be aware of the probability that any mining in the Koongarra Project area would be very detrimental to the South Alligator River, as Koongarra lies in the catchment area of that river near the Nourlangie Creek. In the light of his determination to protect the river, will the Minister give an undertaking to support my private member's Bill to repeal the partially unproclaimed Koongarra Project Area Act passed illegally by the Fraser Government on the last day on which it held the balance of power in the Senate and against which the Australian Labor Party spoke so vehemently at the time?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator McLean would be aware, I have made it clear on a number of occasions that I thought the most likely result was that mining at Coronation Hill would go ahead. But, of course, the proviso to that has always been that the environmental impact statement, which took so long to prepare but was handed to me just a couple of weeks ago on site at Coronation Hill, revealed that the mining could proceed without damaging the South Alligator River. Of course, it is that river which gives life to so many of the things that make Kakadu the very special place that it is. I undertook to make sure that I did my job of protecting the river and, once we have examined that fairly weighty document that has been handed to us by the joint venturers, I will be in a position to at least make a recommendation to the Government.

ANSWER.PARA: In so far as the Koongarra mine is concerned, of course, any mining, if it were to take place there, could only take place if the Government, or, in particular, the Labor Party, were to change its uranium mining policy. The Prime Minister has announced that there will be no consideration of such a change by the Party until its 1991 conference, which is some time away. If a vote were to be held on the subject today, I think there would be no change to the policy and Koongarra would not go ahead. But it is difficult to predict what will happen in two years' time, so I can say no more than that. As far as what possible damage uranium mining at Koongarra might do to the South Alligator, from my inspections of Koongarra-which are not backed up by scientific evidence, but are based on having a look-I would have thought it somewhat easier to prevent environmental damage at Koongarra than at perhaps any uranium mine in the country. I doubt very much if it would present the environmental problems that other mines might. From my inspections it certainly appears that mining could be done there without damage to the environment. But of course there is the larger question of uranium mining and whether or not it ought to take place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Consumer Affairs aware of a concerted campaign by several credit reference organisations and providers aimed at discrediting sections of the Privacy Amendment Bill? Will the Minister clarify the reason for one of the main objections by credit providers, namely, that the absence of positive reporting will jeopardise their ability to assess accurately the complete history of a credit applicant? Are there any grounds for objections that the exclusion of access to the commercial credit record of a small business owner or sole trader will increase defaults and bad debts, therefore encouraging fraudulent credit applications?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The short answer to the first part of Senator Colston's question is that there has in fact been a campaign, run very much by those who mouth commitment to privacy principles but who are not quite prepared to have the promise of those principles actually placed in concrete and the performance achieved. At the introduction of the Bill the Government made it clear that it had a number of objectives in this area. One was to tackle the whole question of positive reporting and another was to apply the privacy principles to the credit reporting industry. As I said at the time, and to representatives of the Credit Reference Association of Australia who came to see me on the day of the introduction of the Bill, we were prepared then, and are now, to have constructive consultations on the Bill. In fact, at that meeting we canvassed the question of amendments to the Bill and got a positive response to that. It is fair to say that since then there have been two strata of contribution to the debate: there has been a whole range of constructive bilateral discussions with sections of industry, and there has been the somewhat irrational campaign.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. This matter has been raised on a number of previous occasions. There is a difference between items which are generally listed for debate and specific discussion of a Bill which is on the Notice Paper. The question has invited the Minister to address not the issues but the specifics of a Bill which is now listed for debate and is therefore not in order. There is a standing order which prohibits the anticipation of debate on a particular piece of legislation as distinct from a wider canvass. The Minister should not be allowed to take the opportunity to make an amendment to his second reading speech about a Bill on the Notice Paper which is scheduled for debate.

—The point raised by Senator Puplick is valid. The Minister should not anticipate a debate on a Bill that is on the Notice Paper. I ask the Minister to conclude. He can refer to consultations that have taken place and I think that is where he should leave it.

—Mr President, I will continue and take into account your direction. As I said, there have been some quite constructive consultations and there has been the alternative campaign, which has been based very much on deliberate misinformation. In those consultations the Government has made it clear to the people with whom it has been discussing the Bill that it will maintain the original intention of the Bill, which is to allow a whole range of credit providers-in fact, 90 per cent or thereabouts of the existing users. The Government also made it very clear that the whole question of whether there should be a distinction between personal and commercial files and a bar of access on one when accessing the other is very hard to maintain, although that matter initially came out of consultations and discussions with industry. There will of course be amendments to cover the constructive outcome of the consultations in those two areas and others as well. Out of the consultations has also come a growing awareness of the Government's position-a position that was adopted and endorsed by both the Opposition and the Australian Democrats, who were in opposition to positive reporting. The Government's position on that point has been getting growing support and recognition throughout the community.

ANSWER.PARA: In conclusion, the bilateral consultations with industry have been quite constructive and useful. They will lead to industry's legitimate concerns being taken into account. The Government's commitment ensures that the privacy of individuals with regard to this particular legislation will not be compromised. I must also say that the quite hysterical campaign which has been run has been of no real value to industry and individual members of organisations involved in it. Unfortunately, they will be concerned by some of the reports that have emanated from their peak organisation. However, we have had constructive consultations; they are continuing. I warn those who may be inclined to listen to the Credit Reference Association of Australia or the Australian Credit Forum to have a second thought about that.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer him to the blow-out in the Government's 1988-89 inflation target of 4.5 per cent, and the fact that inflation in the year to June this year is now running at 7.6 per cent. I ask: In what demonstrable way is he expressing his concern about the effect of such high inflation on industry competitiveness? Does he agree that the most effective way to reduce inflation without creating unemployment is more directly to relate wages growth to productivity growth? If the Minister substantially agrees with this, how does he justify his Government's support for wages growth of at least 6.5 per cent this year when productivity is virtually stagnant? Does he not agree that these figures suggest the Government's approach could well be a recipe for inflation and unemployment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be wrong of me not to admit that there were some errors in the Budget forecasting last year.
—Mea culpa.

—Not mea culpa, nostra culpa. Senator Watson asked: In what demonstrable way am I expressing concern about this? I am not a person given to demonstrations, Senator. I do not know what he means by that question. Of course, one must always be concerned about a rate of inflation which is higher than that of one's trading partners. As a matter of fact, I suspect that, compared with that of our trading partners, it is less high now than it was 12 months ago. That is not to the credit of policies adopted in this country, but it is a fact of life that the inflation rate in Australia is not so significantly different from that of our trading partners as it was 12 or 15 months ago.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Watson went on to say, `Look, you have foreshadowed wage increases of 6.5 per cent. Should not wages be related to productivity?'. My answer to that question is; yes, as much as possible, wages ought to be related to productivity, and that is what the award restructuring matters in the Industrial Relations Commission's recent decision are about, as far as possible. It is implicit in Senator Watson's question that we have been enjoying a degree of wage inflation in Australia. In my view that is not correct. That was a characteristic of the period of Liberal Party Government, but in the period of this Government we have not been suffering from what is normally known as wage inflation. Whether that will occur in the future is a matter which will ultimately be determined by the success of the Government's wages policy following the recent decision of the Industrial Relations Commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Should not wages growth move simultaneously with productivity growth? Is not the problem that wages growth is moving ahead of so-called possible growth in productivity?

—Senator Watson asks whether wages growth moving ahead of productivity is not the problem. Had he couched the question in terms of `Is it not a problem that wage growth exceeds productivity', my answer would have been yes. But there are many other problems in terms of the productivity of Australian industries, and so on, which go wider than the question which the honourable senator now asks me by way of a supplementary question. As I am answering Senator Watson's question, I will concentrate on that. We have arguments about productivity change in Australia and what is happening there. All I can say is that I think it is a glib assertion to say that there are no improvements in productivity at the same time as wage increases are taking place.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Is he aware of the arrest and detention by the Myanmar Government of Aung San Suu Kyi, General Secretary of the National League for Democracy; U Tin U, Chairman of the National League for Democracy; and many other NLD members throughout Myanmar? Can he confirm whether Aung San Suu Kyi is presently on a hunger strike in protest at her arrest? If so, what is the state of her health? Has the Australian Government made, or will it make, representations to the Myanmar Government for Aung San Suu Kyi and the other political prisoners to be immediately released? Will the Australian Government point out to the Myanmar authorities that their commitment to hold free and fair elections by May 1990 is inconsistent with the arrest of Aung San Suu Kyi and others? Will the Australian Government inform the Myanmar authorities that the presently suspended Australian aid programs will not be re-started until the Myanmar Government makes substantial progress towards the restoration of human rights and the establishment of free and fair elections in Myanmar?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I very much share Senator Schacht's concern with the matters he has raised. On 25 July I issued a statement expressing the Australian Government's concern and regret at the action taken by the Myanmar Government on 21 July and for serving detention orders on Aung San Suu Kyi and U Tin U. I called for these restrictions to be lifted and pointed out that the exclusion of these leaders from the election process would undermine the capacity of the elections to meet the democratic aspirations of the Myanmar people. It has been reported that Aung San Suu Kyi has been on a hunger strike, as Senator Schacht has said. However, I have to say that detailed information about that remains very scarce, and the precise state of her health is simply unknown to us at this stage. There has been a lot of speculation about it, but no hard information. The Australian Government has also made representations to the Myanmar Government on several occasions through its embassy here in Canberra and through the Australian Embassy in Rangoon, or Yangon as it is now called, against these detentions. We have also made representations about the actions taken against political parties more generally, and also on the death sentences that have recently been passed by a military tribunal on three individuals who are allegedly implicated in the bomb attack on 7 July.

ANSWER.PARA: As to our aid program, apart from continuing humanitarian aid through the United Nations Children's Fund, the only Australian aid project in Myanmar on which work is progressing is the Mandalay dairy project in respect of which I have already indicated the reasons for continuing our assistance, namely to ensure that the very large sum of money that has already been spent will not be wasted in the final engineering stages of that project. Decisions on the resumption of other Australian aid project activities will be subject to our ongoing assessment of the overall situation, including the administrative, logistic and infrastructural environment. I have to say that I am not inclined to pursue the question of reviewing that situation unless there is substantial evident progress toward the restoration of human rights and electoral democracy in that country.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations, follows the answer he gave earlier in Question Time to Senator Watson. Is the Minister aware that the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) figures show that last year's Budget forecast of earnings growth was exceeded by almost 25 per cent, and that the outcome was about six percentage points above estimated labour productivity growth? Given those figures and the Government's estimate of 6.5 per cent average earnings growth this financial year-a figure on which even the Treasurer has cast doubt; a more realistic estimate is probably 8 to 9 per cent-does the Minister really believe that the current wage fixing system is helping Australian industries' international competitive position?

—There seems to be some confusion in the honourable senator's question between average earnings growth and average wage growth. They are different. I am not familiar with the ABS statistic to which he referred, but I will certainly have a look at it.
—And me.
—That includes the honourable senator, executives of major companies and all sorts of people.
—Worse, it includes you.

—It includes me too. And it includes all those sorts of people. The honourable senator's point about productivity and wages growth, which he continually makes in the Senate, is really made in pursuit of his ongoing belief that, somehow, workers do not produce as much as they ought to, bludge on the system and all that--
—Nonsense.
—I have listened for a long time to Senator Parer asking these sorts of questions.
—You are drawing a long bow on that.

—What Senator Parer is talking about is the productive sector of the economy and trying to relate productivity in that sector to average wage growth. Senator Boswell interjected. He would be neither an example of income restraint nor an example of productivity. That simple point I think answers the honourable senator's question.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Comment is made that Australia's high inflation rate results from the fact that our wage increases are far above productivity growth. I take the Minister back to that comment. In his response he indicated that I said people were bludgers, or something. I have never indicated that or intimated that. What I am asking the Minister is whether he believes that the aggregate wages growth, which is far in excess of productivity growth and higher than that of our major trading partners, will provide a basis for a reduction in inflation, economic recovery and improvement of our balance of payments?

—The honourable senator has now corrected his original question and asked me a supplementary question. The question he has now asked by way of a supplementary is essentially the question I was asked by Senator Watson some time ago. The point I make about that is that, as far as possible, wage growth should be related to and dependent on productivity increases. I acknowledged that in an answer to Senator Watson. I went on to explain to him that the award restructuring program and the Industrial Relations Commission's current decision were very much designed to enhance productivity. All sorts of things can enhance productivity-not just award restructuring and things of that kind, but the levels of investment by industry and a whole range of matters which affect productivity. As I understand it, the honourable senator's supplementary question is as to whether our wage growth is exceeding that of some other countries. I think the answer to that question is probably yes, but whether wage levels in this country are anywhere near those of many of those countries which have lesser wage growth at present than Australia is a totally different and a relevant question.

—My question, which is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support, concerns the existing Broome Airport and proposals for a new international airport. Can the Minister confirm whether discussions are under way within the Department for a new, privately owned and managed international airport on Roebuck Station near Broome in the name of Ansett Transport Industries and Australian City Properties Ltd (ACP), the latter company largely owned by Lord Alistair McAlpine? Is the Minister aware of the deal organised by this joint venture and the Broome Shire Council for transferring control and ownership of the existing airport site to the Broome shire to be later handed over to the joint venture in exchange for funding the new McAlpine international airport-a deal which would give ACP a real estate profit of at least $100m? Is the Minister aware that three of the nine Broome shire councillors are employees of Ansett Airlines Ltd, one of the joint venturers for the proposed international airport? Has this project been referred to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories for a full environmental impact study and have alternative sites been considered? In light of the fact that a Federal review of the terms and conditions of the aerodrome local ownership plan has not yet been considered by the Government, and in light of the fact that a Western Australian Government State Strategic Transport Committee has been established to examine this matter, should not all further discussions of the ACP-Ansett Transport Industries plans for an international airport at Broome be put on hold?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised by the Minister, Mrs Kelly, that negotiations are under way between the Commonwealth and the Shire of Broome for the transfer of the existing Broome Airport to the shire. Any transfer would be on the basis that the airport would be open to the public and that open and non-discriminatory access would be provided to all operators.

ANSWER.PARA: I am told by the Minister that she is aware that the shire is separately negotiating with the consortium of Australian City Properties and Ansett for the consortium to operate the airport should transfer negotiations be successfully concluded and for the subsequent development of a new airport by the consortium. The question of whether any new airport would be designated as an international airport has not been raised. The designation of international airports is the responsibility of the Federal Government. Any application for designation of a new Broome Airport or approval of international flights would be considered by the Federal Government on its merits.

Press reports have mentioned very large figures, as Senator Vallentine tells us today, of $50m to $100m for the value of the existing airport. However, such figures bear no relationship to the evaluations available to the Government. The Minister has seen reports to the effect that three of the nine Broome shire councillors are employees of Ansett. At present, she is not able to confirm them. Clearly, the Commonwealth is negotiating with the shire council as the duly elected representatives of the community. The current negotiations concern the transfer of the existing airport. However, before any new airport was constructed, the proponent would be required to meet the requirements of environmental legislation. I am advised that a tentative site for a new airport has been selected but has not yet been fully evaluated. We are not aware of the extent to which alternative sites have been investigated.

Finally, the review of the aerodrome local ownership plan is still under consideration by the Government. Nonetheless, the model for airport transfers, established in recent transfers of airports at Kalgoorlie, Mackay, Mount Gambier and Camooweal, is clearly to the benefit of local communities. It is the judgment of the Minister that Broome would benefit from equivalent arrangements.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In view of the Royal Australian Air Force base at Curtin currently being used by commercial airline companies and capable of taking large international aircraft as well, has a feasibility study been undertaken by the Government to determine the need for an international airport in Broome, Derby being only a couple of hundred kilometres up the track? Secondly, is it a fact that Lord McAlpine, a major shareholder of Australian City Properties, does not have permanent resident status in Australia? Is that relevant to the Government's consideration of this project, especially as he has already received a substantial amount of taxpayers' funding under the Western Australian Development Corporation for his Club Broome development?

—I will refer those very substantial supplementary questions to the Minister. In relation to feasibility studies, I do not believe that any such feasibility study has been carried out. It would only be a matter of responding to a request for international status were one to be made. There are already a very large number of international gateways into Australia, given our population size. I think the onus would be very much on someone wanting to establish a new international status to make a very compelling case, because of the infrastructural costs with customs, quarantine and everything else that is associated with that. I do not say that in any spirit of negativism so far as the entrepreneurial enthusiasms of those in the Broome area are concerned, but just as a small matter to be borne in mind, given the long history of entrepreneurs in various parts of Australia talking about new international gateways in an environment where we already have a large number of those.

—I refer the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to his press release of 24 July, to which he himself referred a moment ago, concerning Myanmar and to that part of his press release which welcomes the Myanmar Government's promise of elections in April and May 1990 and his statement that `since then the election program has been adhered to'. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is important that I respond to some of the specific allegations that were made during the recess by the so-called Opposition Waste Watch Committee because they have had a considerable public airing, not only on the Today program on 2 August but also in substantial slabs of the print media, as, no doubt, the allegations were meant to. For example, a headline in the Sun on 12 August referred to `a $250m aid waste bungle'. A number of other assertions of that kind appeared in the print media. The particular claim that was made on the television program was that there was waste in Australia's overseas aid program amounting to some $200m to $250m over an unspecified period-that is, up to one quarter of our annual aid budget. The actual press release that was issued by the Committee on 3 August identified specific instances in the aid area of what it claimed was waste which, even on the most optimistic or broad ranging reading of the claims, totalled $61m, not $250m, spread over eight financial years. If one looks at the specific allegations that were made, it is clear that any such claims are utterly without foundation.

ANSWER.PARA: I will mention as quickly as I can some of the projects that were referred to. The proposed construction of a bridge over the Mekong River between Thailand and Laos was the largest item identified by the Committee as wasteful. The preliminary estimate for the design and construction was $35m over a five-year period. This project-the so-called Kangaroo Bridge, as it has been identified by the Thai and Loatian governments-is potentially of enormous economic and political significance to the countries of the region, and indeed to Australia. It will be the only bridge across the Mekong. It will be a very important trade conduit, having regard to the fact that the whole of Indo-China is potentially about to explode in terms of its economic development. It is enormously significant in terms of the total regional politics of the region and is an expression of Australia's commitment to it. A quite bizarre claim was made in respect of that.

On the face of it, there was a slightly more plausible criticism of our aid to Brunei, Jamaica, Barbados and the Bahamas. The great majority of Australia's assistance to these countries in recent years has been in the form of subsidies to private overseas students. Although this scheme has served its purpose effectively in the past, it has been the subject of a full review over the last 12 months and is being phased out from the end of this calendar year. The savings that will be so made will be directed, in whole, to a new aid scholarship scheme which is targeted to focus much more precisely on the needs of particular deserving students, not just from developing countries worldwide but from developing countries within Australia's priority area. None of the four countries will be the subject of scholarships under the new scheme-certainly not the Caribbean ones-in the way the Committee mentioned.

There is an allegation that in Myanmar-Burma-$68,000 was wasted on the purchase of agricultural motorbikes as part of a dairy development project. The motorbikes were supplied for use by veterinarians and artificial inseminators. This is the first time I have ever heard of a motorbike being used for artificial insemination, but that is another question. After the bikes were provided it was realised that some of the intended users, in particular women, had difficulty in handling them. We are now looking at the possibility of providing smaller machines. The bikes were chosen by the Burmese Government because of the height of the body of the bike above ground level. This is important given the roughness of the terrain. The question related particularly to what has happened to those bikes that cannot be ridden by the inseminators. Surplus bikes have not been thrown on the scrap heap or given away to other needy persons; they are currently in storage and it is expected that they will be used when the project is fully operational.

In Kiribati in the Pacific, Australia has spent some $660,000 in support of the redevelopment and extension of the one serviceable hotel in that country. That was argued to be waste because it was said that it was just to provide a comfortable berth for heads of government--

TALK.START.PARA: —You would not even stay at it. You stayed on the ship. You brought a naval vessel.

—I did not stay in it myself during the South Pacific Forum. That expenditure is a perfect example of entirely appropriate aid to a country which has an extraordinarily narrow economic base, as Senator Hill will well testify. As tourism is one of the very few industries of any significant revenue potential, an economic appraisal of that project found it to be quite sound in terms of cost effectiveness and likely usage rates. It is just bizarre to be calling that an example of misplaced aid.

ANSWER.PARA: Again, the Committee considers that our assistance to small Indian Ocean island countries-the Maldives, Mauritius and the Seychelles-was a questionable form of aid support. But all those three countries have particularly low standards of living. For example, in the Maldives the per capita income is just $300 per annum. Tourism is one of the very few sectors in each of these economies that show some signs of generating income. That industry deserves the kind of Australian support that was given in the aid projects funding in question.

I have just two more specific examples I want to mention. The Committee identified Australian support for a women workers conference in Hong Kong as being questionable. That was a regional conference of Asian women workers from the entire area held in Hong Kong but it was designed to benefit all the countries of the region. The final specific item mentioned was the provision of $26,000 for a day care centre for poor children in E1 Salvador to assist in the training of women in child-care. I think it is just a demonstration of prejudice to claim that that is wasted or questionable aid. It is part of our women in development program. It might be argued that it would be better directed to priorities in the region rather than in Central America. I can understand that argument, but a particular project of that kind is entirely justifiable in its own terms. It is wholly extravagant to talk in terms of waste.

Let me finally say, Mr President, that while I recognise that there are risks in managing an aid program of some $1.1 billion spread over a very large number of countries, things can go wrong in terms of targeting strategies, delivery and accountability in particular projects. Nonetheless, the Australian taxpayer can be satisfied that very rigorous risk management practices are in place. The Australian International Development Assistance Bureau has developed a very effective system of project monitoring, evaluation and financial management. The whole program is subject to detailed scrutiny through the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, as well as other vehicles such as Estimates committees. It is a matter of concern that unfounded allegations of this kind can be made. They do tend to undermine bipartisan support, which is very important for the Australian aid program. It is a cheap and shoddy little exercise that does those participating in it no credit at all.
