TALK.START.PARA: —On 16 June Senator Boswell asked me a question concerning consultation with the Norfolk Island Government on the telecommunications Bill, and I have the answer. Commonwealth legislation does not extend to Norfolk Island unless expressed so to do. Since the grant of self-government in 1979 the Government has pursued a policy of consultation with the Norfolk Island Government, so far as is practicable, on proposals to apply Commonwealth laws to the Territory. The policy is reflected in the Cabinet and legislation handbooks. On occasion it is not practicable to consult for reasons of urgency or where, by convention, consultation normally does not occur-for example, Budget legislation.

ANSWER.PARA: The telecommunications Bill establishes Austel, which the Government was committed to having in place by 1 July. By the time the Bill was available there was little time for consultation prior to the introduction of the legislation. The 70-page exposure draft of the Bill sent by the Department of Transport and Communications on 22 March 1989 was received in the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories on 29 March 1989. Comments were sought by 3 April. The Bill was forwarded to Norfolk Island on 30 March in a departmental bag. Unfortunately, the Bill did not arrive on the island until 10 April. It was immediately referred to the Norfolk Island Government, whose comments were received by my Department on 20 April and forwarded to the Department of Transport and Communications the same day. The legislation was not passed by the Senate until 7 June.

My Department devotes considerable resources to consulting with the Norfolk Island Government on the application of Commonwealth legislation to the Territory but the process relies, among other things, on initiating departments following the established procedures for consultation outlined in Cabinet and legislation handbooks. The Norfolk Island Government often makes sound suggestions to improve legislation; however, it is the prerogative of the relevant Minister to decide whether or not to agree to amendments proposed by the Norfolk Island Government. Periodically my Department writes to all departments emphasising the need to consult with the Norfolk Island Government at an early stage on all legislative proposals affecting the Territory. The last such occasion was in January 1988. A further reminder will be issued in the near future.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Chaney proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The need for the Government to adopt a new approach to industrial relations which is enterprise-based, to encourage Australians to work together more productively to reduce our foreign debt and to stop the slide in living standards.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the course of Question Time we have had an unusually full set of public galleries. To the rear of the Opposition benches we have had a large number of pensioners who are probably here to keep an eye on the Government's Budget performance, and sitting behind the Government benches have been quite a number of school children. Looking at the people in the gallery has reminded me of how important the issue of the Australian economy is to the future of those children and to the continued welfare of those elderly citizens.

SPEECH.PARA: The debate on industrial relations which the Opposition is promoting on Budget day relates to the concern which is felt in the community about where Australia is going. It is quite clear to any of us who have spent time with those in the Australian community during the recess that there is a very deep concern about the future of Australia. I do not think there is any doubt that that concern flows not from the immediate pain of interest rates, it does not flow so much from the immediate concern of people who feel that 40c in the dollar on the extra dollar of overtime is an excessive tax impost, although they are the sorts of things that people raise as one moves around Australia. Far more fundamentally, people are concerned about the spectre of foreign debt, the general sense of declining living standards and, indeed, the general sense of national decline in a comparative sense.

In the course of talking to people around Australia, on a couple of occasions I have compared the cents in Australia of 25 years ago with the cents in Australia today. The situation is very different. The Minister at the table, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), makes some muttered interjection but my point is that over that generation, that 25-year period, there has been a growth not in the certainties of Australian life but in the uncertainties, and I think that economic uncertainties are at the head of that.

This morning in the Australian newspaper an article by Maxwell Newton helped to encapsulate some of the concern expressed. In Queensland, for example, there is a concern about the level of foreign investment-Japanese investment in particular. In Maxwell Newton's article we read an account of our comparative wealth today in our region as compared with that of a few years ago and we see a process of steady decline and a situation where the purchase of Australia by foreigners has become increasingly cheap. The simple reality is that a Japanese person wishing to buy a slice of Queensland in 1989 does so at half the yen cost of 1983. All of these things are simply part of a pattern of decline which the Opposition has been talking about and is deeply concerned about; and it reflects the deep concerns felt within the community.

Tonight a Budget will be handed down. The truth is that no Budget will alter that decline. It may be that good macro-economic settings will improve the situation and poor macro-economic settings will make it worse, but the truth is that we will not solve Australia's problems by sleight of hand or the passage of Acts of Parliament, and we will not solve Australia's problems in a Budget. We will solve Australia's problems if we become a more effective producer of the goods and services that our people and the rest of the world want. There is a widespread understanding of that in Australia, and a widespread desire for change and for the Government to come to grips with that reality.

One of the things which should encourage any government of Australia at the end of the 1980s is what Mr Keating talked about, and that is the increased understanding by the Australian people-I think they certainly do understand it-that we in Australia have to become more competitive and more productive if we are to overcome the pressures of which, as I said before, high interest rates are merely a symptom. They are a very unpleasant symptom for those Australians who are buying a house, running a small business or a farm and who need to borrow working capital. Of course, they are a very unpleasant symptom, but they are a symptom rather than a cause of our present problems and the uncertainty that exists in the community.

I believe it is in Australia's national interest as far as possible to find the common ground which exists as to what our problems are and how they ought to be solved. When one looks at the explosion in our foreign debt and its growth from a net figure of $23 billion in March 1983 when this Government came to power to a net figure, just six years later in March 1989, of $103 billion, the worsening situation since then, and the rapid growth of assets in Australia held by foreigners-which is again simply a symptom of the relative weakness of Australia in our region and elsewhere-one must ask: What are the causes?

Mr Keating did us some service. In 1986 he described us as heading for a banana republic status. In April 1989 he said that our fundamental problem is that we consume more than we produce. The fundamental Keating, Button and Hawke strategy has been to impose very high interest rates on the Australian people so that their consumption is reduced. It is a simple application of one of the tools that the Treasurer and the Government have to reduce the consumption of the people of Australia. That is on the record. As recently as 12 July the Treasurer said:

. . . if we did not slow the demand down so that the economy can live within its own product other than simply spilling into imports and overseas debt, then the catastrophic change which would then come by years and years of neglect-if that were to be the position-it would be very harmful to those people.

It would be very harmful to the young children and the elderly who are in the gallery today. The point that the Opposition has been hammering is the point which has finally been acknowledged by Mr Keating-that is, perhaps there is a more positive approach to solving Australia's problems. The suppression of Australian living standards has to be seen as an unpleasant, temporary expedient-not an expedient that should have been the Government's agenda from 1983 to 1989. The agenda should have been to increase the productive capacity of Australia. We find, from looking at statements made by Mr Keating a little later last July, that lifting production was very clearly becoming the national economic imperative. We find Mr Keating swinging around to the view that the imperative is to do something about production. In a radio interview in that same week he said:
Factories needed to lift production and workers needed to work double shifts ``to pull more product out''.

We saw a sudden embracing by the Treasurer of the idea that the real approach to Australia's problems is to do something about the production of wealth. That reflects a view which has long been expressed by the Opposition.

The Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button), who will take part in this debate, and I welcome that, is often very slick and glib and pushes aside the issues raised by the Opposition. He did it again in his response to a question by Senator Parer today. Senator Parer again raised the imbalance between wage rises and the increase in productivity in Australia. The Leader of the Government pushed that aside and accused Senator Parer of accusing members of the Australian work force of being bludgers. That is quite untrue. The fact is that Senator Button seems to find it very difficult to come to grips with the simple proposition that if we have money wage increases which are not underpinned by capacity to pay, then the whole thing is a lie: the wage rise is taken by the next round of inflation. Senator Button knows that has been the pattern and he knows that Australian workers, who he says have shown wage restraint, have in fact received money wage increases far higher than their foreign counterparts but they have not received real wage increases because the inflation rate has gobbled them up. The Government has robbed the Australian work force.

TALK.START.PARA: —They cannot see real wage increases while their productivity will not allow it.

—Of course. In this debate we are seeking to come to grips with the real issues that will enable Australian workers to obtain real wage increases, and we are seeking to have something done about the status of our debt.

SPEECH.PARA: The final quote from Mr Keating recognises again a truth which the Government has not acted upon-that it is fundamental to our success that we move to a more flexible labour market. In May last year Mr Keating declared that labour market reform was `the last great area of change to be overcome'. He said that the policy objective was to create a flexible industrial relations system in which wages and conditions reflected the different levels of prosperity in different industries. That reflects again some of the thinking advanced by the Opposition for some years now.

In this debate, on a day when all our attention is focused on the economic future of our country, the Opposition is fundamentally saying that the Government must adopt a new approach to industrial relations if it is to have any chance of getting Australia out of its present difficulties and easing the gloom and depression, the sense that Australia does not have a good future, the sort of future that we are entitled to. We think the Government needs to move to an enterprise based approach to industrial relations, which will encourage Australians to work together productively. The Government must cease its support for the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) promotion of 20 large trade unions without regard for the fundamental truth that to get a productivity lift in Australia we want not a smaller number of trade unions per se but a single trade union in each enterprise, if there is to be a trade union there at all. We want to do away with the multiplicity of unions in workplaces, which promotes workplace inefficiency.

I emphasise that if we are to have an industrial relations system that works, we need to have a system which is enforceable, which is fair to both sides. As Mr Willis said in 1987, `If we are to have an effective arbitration system, it has to be one where there is compliance and both sides are bound'. He said that the present system and the present remedies are moribund. He then proposed that the system be made accountable and enforceable. He withdrew his proposals in the teeth of ACTU opposition. We say that there is a need for that trio of changes in the approach to industrial relations adopted by the Government and hence in the community-a move to an enterprise based approach which will encourage Australians to work together productively, promotion of a union structure which will complement that, and a system where both sides are bound to the rules and do not simply go their own way. These are not new propositions from the Opposition. In our industrial relations policy, which was reissued a year ago, we made our views clear. I quote from the policy:

The key to good industrial relations and higher productivity is the strength and quality of the relationship between employer and employee. We need a system where employers and employees work as a team.

The current system places the emphasis of industrial relations away from the workplace, thereby encouraging destructive `them and us' attitudes. It creates the perception that industrial relations is about winners and losers.

Our policy is about ensuring that the focus of industrial relations is where it belongs-at the level of the individual enterprise. At workplace level employers and employees can see most clearly that they have a common interest in the success of the enterprise.
We reaffirmed that view in Future Directions, issued last December, when we said:

We want to encourage management and employees to work more closely together to raise productivity. This will lead to higher real wages, and more satisfying and secure jobs. We also want to see people gaining a stake in their enterprise through employee share ownership, profit sharing and employee participation.
We went on to say:

The current industrial relations system is based on the old adversarial approach, where workers and bosses were assumed always to be fighting each other. This is no longer the case. Employers are beginning to realise that their employees are their best asset, while most employees understand that their own prosperity and security is tied up with the success of their enterprise. People want to be treated as individuals, able to have control over their own working arrangements, not to have them dictated by union rules.

I welcome the extent to which the present system and the Government have tried to move in some small way down the path that we have indicated. I know that the Leader of the Government in the Senate will get up and start talking about award restructuring, how this is very much along the lines of what is being sought and that this is the key to improved efficiency. The truth is that a survey of employers has shown that 80 per cent do not believe that they will not get any productivity gain from award restructuring. The sad fact of the matter is that if one reads the leading agreement in the award restructuring area-I invite the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce who is at the table, if he has not already done so, to read the metal trades agreement which is at the foremost of the push for award restructuring-one finds in that document on its face an acknowledgment of the enormous difficulty of moving that theoretical restructuring of award arrangements down into what is actually happening in the workplace, and the establishment of committees and arrangements. There is a desperate attempt-supplemented by taxpayers' funds from the Government-to translate a theory entered into by the leaders of the industry at both the trade union and employer level into reality within the workplaces of Australia. There are one million workplaces in Australia-I exaggerate, perhaps it is 800,000-and we cannot get those Australians working together productively in the way that is required by some centralised direction. The system has to encourage the process to be one that grows from the bottom up.

I believe that the Business Council of Australia is doing some valuable work in trying to isolate what makes Australian enterprises more productive. It has yet to release its report, but it was interesting to see an interview with Mr Fred Hilmer who has headed up that task force and who is now moving in as the Dean of the Graduate School of Management in Sydney.

TALK.START.PARA: —Professor Hilmer.

—I am corrected by my colleague. What Professor Hilmer had to say in an interview which was reported in the industrial relations and management newsletter makes clear that there really is a more satisfactory way of getting Australia out of its difficulties than the suppression of demand and the impoverishment of the Australian people, whether it is through high interest rates, high taxes or any of the other mechanisms which are available to Mr Keating to suppress the demand and the living standards of Australians. Mr Hilmer stated:

SPEECH.PARA: We are 25 per cent behind the rest of the world in our productivity. We must have more flexibility to change and adapt our work methods (how we do things) and patterns (timing).

We all know that when the ACTU sent out its directive to the trade union movement about award restructuring it said, `You must not touch the hours of work'. One area which is most central to getting more effective work in Australian workplaces is off the agenda as far as the ACTU is concerned. That gives honourable senators some idea of the difficulties faced in individual enterprises. Honourable senators should look at the example that Mr Hilmer chooses to air in this interview. He looked at plants operating in Australia and overseas and he compared two operations which were similar, having the same machinery and product. He stated:
Yet when we compared their productivity, the Australian plant was 20 per cent behind the European operation.

We are not talking here about lazy workers, we are talking about people who, at both the management and employee level, have seen too much of the running of the enterprise taken out of their hands by bureaucrats of one sort or another. What we are promoting and saying is that we must push the affairs of the workplace back to the individual enterprise so that efficiencies will be obtained, so that Australia has the future that it deserves and so that we cease to head inexorably towards being the poor white trash of Asia. The workplace focus is central to our view. We have specific proposals as to how to promote it.

Let me touch very quickly on union structure: demarcation disputes do not flow from a multiplicity of small unions. The statistics make it quite clear that the demarcation disputes that bedevil production in Australia are a product of conflict between large unions. There is no evidence that the union structure being promoted by Mr Kelty will reduce the number of unions within enterprises. The truth is that this Government has sought to get greater efficiency-I give it credit for having done so-in some of our defence industries. It has worked hard to reduce the number of unions within the enterprises. It reopened a dockyard on the condition that the number of unions was reduced, I think to three. The same condition applied with the submarine project. We say that the Government should be joining with us to encourage a structure of trade unions which will ensure that the movement is towards single enterprise bargaining units. This is not an anti-union bash or a policy which is against trade unions. Our policy, even in voluntary agreements, is that if workers wish to use trade unions as their agent, then that is their right and we would defend that right as strongly as we would defend their right not to join a trade union. The unions have a place if they can earn a place by performance, but the structure which is being promoted by the ACTU with the cooperation of the Government is not a structure which is in the interests of efficient production in Australia.

Finally, I will touch on the question of enforceability. I have already quoted Mr Willis. In May 1987 he acknowledged that for the system to work properly it must bind both sides. It is notorious that the airline pilots ignored the direction of the Industrial Relations Commission. They even ignored the requirement that they attend before the Commission at specific hearings and they have said that they will go on ignoring it if it suits their purposes. The ACTU has made statements about the extent to which it will accept the national wage case depending on the outcome of the application of the case to five key industries-take it or leave it, according to whether the decision suits. In May 1987 Mr Willis said that it was not good enough, it was not the way the system should work. In August 1987, the leader of the ACTU, Mr Crean, said, `You cannot have a Bill with improved compliance provisions', and this Government caved in. I say to the Government, `We will bring on that Bill of which I have given notice today and give you another opportunity to reconsider that'. We want a system that is accountable, flexible and fair and which will be productive for Australia and get it out of the mess that is causing such depression and pessimism around the country. I commend this matter to the Minister's attention. I hope that he will do more in this response than the backhand, offhand efforts that he showed in Question Time in response to the matters which were raised with him by us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very unfair of Senator Chaney to characterise my answer to a badly couched question as being a back off, as he put it. In looking at this matter of public importance, I certainly agree with the need for a better approach to industrial relations. I certainly agree with Australians working together more productively to reduce the foreign debt and stop the slide in living standards.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to say something about the observations which Senator Chaney made at the beginning of his speech before he got on to the subject of the matter of public importance. Before doing so, I must say that I did expect this matter of public importance today. After all, it is essentially the speech which Senator Chaney was going to give to the luncheon in Perth last week which was cancelled because, as I understand it, nobody was interested.

TALK.START.PARA: —That epitomised your response to all these issues, Senator.
—It is inevitable in this business, as the honourable senator knows. The promotional pamphlet for that lunch said the following of Senator Chaney:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . his vision for the future will have a direct bearing on the direction and future prosperity of this State and Australia . . .

Senator Chaney himself told the Australian that he planned to talk about the impediments to international competitiveness; namely, impediments in the labour market. It is not surprising to me that that speech which was not given has been recycled in the Senate today prior to the Budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many of your side are here to listen to you? Four of them, and it is compulsory attendance.

—The point I am simply trying to make is that having failed with a voluntary audience, Senator Chaney comes here today with a captive one, of which Senator Crichton-Browne is a classic example, if I might say so.
—I am here by choice; yours are not here by choice.
—They are volunteers.
—You have four here and they are all asleep.

—That is most unfair. Senator Childs is not asleep; he is looking very alert. Senator Chaney began his comments with an expression of deep concern about the future of Australia-something which I and many Ministers in this Government and some in the Opposition share. He cited examples of his concern being reflected in what he referred to as general talks around Australia. He went on to say, for example, that people in Queensland were concerned about the level of foreign investment, particularly Japanese investment, in Australia. He said that these investments were being made at half the 1983 yen cost. Senator Chaney's speech could be made in the United States, in Canada, and in a number of other countries as a result of the enormous appreciation of the yen in the last few years. The fact that Japan is now the richest country on earth means that it can determine the future of the United States economy--
—You are not denying that the Australian dollar has fallen during your administration, are you?

—I am not denying that for a moment, but the fall against the trade weighted index has been much less than it has been against the dollar, and it has been much more consistent. The yen is included in that basket. Senator Chaney went on to say that we need to become a more effective producer and to deal with the problem of consuming more than we produce. He referred to Mr Keating making that statement with which I entirely agree. After all, only in two of the last 13 years has Australia exported more by value than it has imported. Those two years were 1985 and 1986. Of course, that has some relevance to Senator Stone's interjection. Senator Chaney talked about the Treasurer's view that lifting production should be on the agenda, and I cannot but agree with that. He then went on to say that I cannot come to grips with the fact that money wages cannot be paid unless there is the capacity to pay. That proposition is quite sensible in itself, but it is totally unrelated to the reality of the current situation in Australia where employers are not backward in being prepared to pay higher wages-not at all.
—Some employers.
—I think it goes further than that. It is largely related to very high levels of profitability.
—Stop talking to Comalco and go and talk to a few small businessmen.

—I will stop talking to Comalco if the honourable senator wants me to-but I have not been doing so. I can come to grips with Senator Chaney's proposition, but I do not think it has much bearing on the current wages problem, which the honourable senator was concerned to address. If Senator Stone will stop talking for just a minute, I will continue with the rest of what I have to say. Again, Senator Chaney came back to the question of relative productivity. There are all sorts of arguments about the measure of productivity and there are many arguments about what induces better productivity, whether they be issues in the labour market, whether they be issues relating to investment, or whether they be issues relating to the use of capital investment. There are a whole range of issues which determine productivity. It is not just about labour market issues on their own, although I agree that they are very important.

SPEECH.PARA: What Senator Chaney is advocating in the course of his remarks is a system which, as he put it, would put industrial relations at the enterprise level; it would provide for flexibility in wage negotiations at that level, and so on. There are two warnings I would have to offer about that. I agree absolutely that the more we can introduce flexibility into the wages system and the more we can have industry and enterprise level negotiations on wages and other matters, the better the system will be. But if there is a rapid introduction of enterprise based wage bargaining, as advocated by the Opposition, I believe we are likely to face two major problems. The first problem relates to the fact that currently the non-traded goods and services sector of the economy has been growing at a faster rate than the traded goods sector. There is a very real danger that the more protected non-traded sector-which includes sections of the public services throughout Australia-is likely to bid for scarce skilled labour by paying higher wages, to the detriment of the traded sector and eventually our trade and inflation performance. Secondly, such an approach will risk the loss of control over one of the most important economic parameters-aggregate wage growth. The ability to maintain moderate wage growth in the face of a wide variety of labour market circumstances is absolutely critical. It is no good having a policy which says that the Industrial Relations Commission is to monitor the rate of wages growth. Governments, I believe, have to be prepared actively to influence the level of wage growth. This was recognised on 8 August by no less an authority than the former Leader of the Opposition, Mr John Howard, when he was describing some of his reasons for his current optimism about Australia. He said that we have had a good farm season. He also said:
We also get the benefit of the strengths of the world economy and we are also, unlike 1982 and 1974, we are not experiencing a major wages breakout . . .

The importance of the question of aggregate wages, of having some capacity to influence aggregate wage levels, and the importance of wage growth in the traded goods sector as against the non-traded goods sector cannot, in my view, be overestimated and lightly danced over by references to some of the admitted deficiencies in the present and historically based system of dealing with these issues in Australia. I hope-and I think we would all agree-that enterprise flexibility can be achieved through plant level implementation of new awards, certified agreements and the relaxation of demarcation rules even under the present system. The current wage approach policy of the Government and of the Industrial Relations Commission towards wage fixing guidelines maintains a framework for a sustainable wages system. It maintains the national framework but it also allows for productivity negotiations and workplace reform at the individual enterprise level. I want to refer to some examples of that in a minute. I must say again that an enterprise approach under present economic conditions will lead to a wages explosion-or could do-akin to those in 1974 and 1982, which were referred to by Mr Howard in his comments on 8 August.

The present wages system allows quite revolutionary changes in the Australian context in dealing with questions relating to work practices at the enterprise level, especially from the reduction in the number of unions and awards which individual companies presently face. Whether they be companies, unions or employees, they have to work at it. A number of companies and unions are taking advantage of sections 115 and 118 of the new industrial relations legislation to implement special certified agreements. These agreements enable parties to achieve their mutual goals in a more workable environment than they have had in the past. They allow for greater flexibility in negotiations over wages and conditions, and the procedures of the Industrial Relations Act provide a safeguard against the risk of exploitation by either party or decisions which are totally inconsistent with the problems of national wage case principles and whether those decisions are inconsistent and contrary to the national interest.

Let me give examples of some of the success stories where people and companies have worked at these issues. For example, two certified agreements were ratified by the Industrial Relations Commission for ICI Australia Ltd-one at Mayfield in New South Wales and one at Gladstone in Queensland. Each of these agreements, which were certified under Industrial Relations Commission rules, contains employment conditions common to managers and production employees alike. They contain performance-based pay provisions. Demarcation is no longer an issue, with all production employees classified as plant technicians. Ultimately, ICI hopes to have individual agreements setting wages and conditions at each of its plants in Australia. Its priority is to develop training and career paths within the context of restructuring awards. The company is in the process of having discussions to implement these things throughout its plants in Australia. That is the result of a company which is prepared to work at it with its employees, as my colleague Senator Chaney would enjoin people to do. People ought to deal with these things at the plant or enterprise level. When a company comes along and does it we do not hear too much about it, but how many companies are doing it?

I will give another example-and Senator Stone will probably interject because I have been talking to Comalco Aluminium Ltd again. Comalco is using the new Industrial Relations Act to process through the Commission an arrangement with the Federated Ironworkers Association of Australia at its joint venture Southern Aluminium plant in Tasmania. When this agreement is ratified one union will cover the workers doing all classifications of work regardless of traditional demarcation lines. These things are happening under the existing systems where companies, employees and unions are prepared to work at them. That is very encouraging, in spite of all the concerns Senator Chaney expressed about these matters, I felt in a much more general way.

There are various views about these issues and about whether the pace of reform is sufficient. Senator Chaney made reference to the metal trades award restructuring and said that a lot of people believed that nothing would happen. It will happen if they work at it. The impediments which Senator Chaney--

TALK.START.PARA: —Employers generally; it wasn't just metal trades employers.

—No. It will happen if they work at it. Let us go back to the 4 per cent wage increase of a few years ago. Some companies worked at it and they got significant benefits out of it. Some companies will work at award restructuring and they will get benefits out of it; those who do not will not. The impediments which Senator Chaney identified in his speech-and I shuddered because I think he and the companies are right about this-are really bureaucratic impediments in the Australian system; not bureaucratic in the sense of public servants but bureaucratic in the sense of employer organisations, unions and everybody else having bureaucratic structures for dealing with these things. I understand that and I think it is a legitimate criticism which is frustrating but can be overcome by commitment and hard work, as has been done by ICI and Comalco, the two examples I used by way of illustration. Senator Chaney mentioned others in the public sector, such as the Williamstown Naval Dockyard, the submarine project and so on. So we are really left with the decision not so much about the direction of reform --
—Pace is important.
—Pace is important. I am not being critical when I say that Senator Chaney implied that he has some magic wand which will--
—No, I did not.
—The honourable senator did. He talked about Liberal Party industrial relations policy and said, `This stuff is not good enough. Our policy will make it quicker'.
—It is better; it will accelerate the process.

—That is all right. The honourable senator will not mind me saying in this place, for God's sake, that that is presented as a sort of magic wand to fix some of the problems which are not being addressed now. The honourable senator should be very grateful for having a magic wand attributed to him.

SPEECH.PARA: This question about the pace of reform is one which concerns serious-minded people involved in discussing this issue. Mr McLaughlin of the Business Council of Australia said on the Face to Face program on Sunday that he had complained in the past about the pace of reform being too slow but that it is now accelerating. In regard to the present national wage case decision he went on to say:

On balance we think it's a good decision . . . It is now clear that everything that goes on in individual workplaces is up for discussion and secondly, they can be discussed at both award level and enterprise level. That's very important because productivity will come from changes that actually occur in real live workplaces.
He went on:

I think importantly from the perspective of medium to large business the decision last week . . . has the upside that individual companies now really have no excuse if they fail to get productivity improvements of quite large dimensions.
He went on:

We accept the fact that most businesses are still respondent to multi-employer awards, and therefore for the foreseeable future, you are going to have a lot of important negotiations at national level.

That is a perspective from the Executive Director of the Business Council of Australia. I quote particularly from Mr McLaughlin's comment that `individual companies really have no excuse'-one could translate that as being no impediment by government-`if they fail to get productivity improvements of quite large dimensions'. While I share many of the sentiments expressed by Senator Chaney in his speech, although not necessarily the conclusions he draws, I am entitled to ask: What is this matter of public importance, which is directed at us, all about?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Button posed a very valid question when he asked, `What is this matter of public importance all about?'. On the surface, the proposition Senator Chaney is arguing seems attractive. Let us look at the components of the proposition. It is being suggested by Senator Chaney and the Opposition that it is a matter of public importance that the Government change certain things; that the Government adopt a new approach to industrial relations which is enterprise based; that the Government encourage Australians to work together more productively to reduce our foreign debt; and that the Government stop the slide in Australia's living standards.

SPEECH.PARA: There are three inherent propositions in this matter of public importance. The Australian Democrats, like the Government, are attracted to a certain extent by some of those components. For instance, it is unarguable and unquestionable that Australians should be encouraged to work together more productively to reduce our foreign debt; we accept that. It is unquestionable that the slide in Australia's living standard should be arrested. We accept that. However, we contend that it is questionable as to whether this would be the outcome of the Government adopting what is really the Opposition's industrial relations policy, namely, a policy based on the concept of enterprise based unions.

As I have said in this place in previous debates, particularly the debate relating to the Industrial Relations Bill 1988, which passed in this Senate last year, essentially there are two fundamental concepts and approaches to industrial relations. They are represented on the one hand by the Government and on the other hand by the Opposition. The Australian Democrats see legitimacy and validity in arguments advanced by both sides on the industrial relation issue. However, we are not prepared to accept outright that all will be resolved by a sudden transition from one model to the other. Indeed, in the passage of the Industrial Relations Bill we argued that it was in the best interests of this nation that there be a gradual transition. In fact, we observed that there has been a significant transition in the nature of industrial relations in this country in the last decade.

Senator Chaney has pointed out, I believe quite rightly, that when the Opposition comes to power, as indeed it eventually will-I would not like to predict when-Australian industrial relations will move in the direction inherent in the fundamentals of this proposition, namely, towards an industrial relations model based on enterprise unions. We accept that that will be an outcome as a result of a change of government. However, the Australian Democrats see an inherent danger in the ultimate power and responsibility for industrial relations being given as glibly, strongly and overtly to employers as it has lain in the hands of employees in this country for a number of decades. The possible use of the principle of `divide and conquer' is quite obviously an inherent danger in the alternative model. In the same way as unionism grew out of the fundamental reality of `united we stand, divided we fall', so, alternatively, in the Opposition's model of industrial relations, there is the inherent danger of pursuit of the principle of `divide and conquer'.

Even now, this is apparent in some of the frayed edges of industrial relations: for example, the proposal to do away with maternity leave in defence related industries, a proposition that has been debated in those industries in just the last few weeks, and which has been resolved. We believe that inherent in that proposition of denial of the right to maternity leave was an indication that privileges must be, and will inevitably be, conceded one by one when the alternative model prevails. In other words, we see the possibility of the erosion of hard won pay and conditions as the real issue that must be addressed by Australian workers when confronted with the alternative model. There has been a long, hard toil for the conditions of pay and allowances won by Australian workers. We suggest that they will need to guard them very closely when the Opposition is at the industrial relations reins.

The Australian Democrats support the current industrial relations system for three basic reasons. It is based on conciliation rather than confrontation. The objective in Australian industrial relations for decades has been to move from confrontation to conciliation. That has been achieved substantially in Australian industrial relations in the last couple of decades. That fundamental reality is now incorporated in a rational Industrial Relations Act which was enacted last year. The Australian Democrats believe that the present industrial relations system retains the best features of what has evolved in industrial relations in Australia. It has put aside the worst and retained the best. We see that gradual transition of capitalising and building upon the best as being appropriate. It was also developed in consultation with the relevant industrial organisation.

It rests on the principle of accord. What about this principle of accord? The prices and incomes accord is still holding up rather well, although with some difficulty, after a number of years. Indeed, it is a principle that has received the praise of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development. The President of South Korea, Mr Roh Tae Woo, recently invited an Australian delegation consisting of Mr Simon Crean, President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, Mr Bert Evans, Executive Director of the Metal Trades Industry Association, and Mr Ross Garnaut, an adviser to the Prime Minister, to visit South Korea and explain the workings of the accord system. This must be an indication that something about the Australian industrial relations system is working. It certainly is working. It has been an effective system.

The Australian Democrats have a positive attitude towards some aspects of enterprise based unions, which would allow for greater involvement of workers and management in the setting of long-term goals for a particular enterprise, such as increasing productivity and output, increasing skills of workers and management through training and re-training schemes, and increasing the penetration of foreign markets. That is one advantage of the enterprise based unions model. It would facilitate increased sharing by workers of management decisions and possibly profit sharing once a company had achieved its output, productivity and profitability aims. Of course, we note that the profitability aims could be jacked up to the point where there would be little left for workers to share after shareholders have made their claims on profit.

We acknowledge that the certified agreements provisions in the Industrial Relations Act 1988 enable enterprise bargaining after Industrial Relations Commission approval has been gained. This could indicate that we are already slowly moving towards enterprise based unions in some situations. However, we must see how well the current provisions work before going further in that direction. In other words, we do not believe it is sensible or reasonable to expect a rapid transition from one model to the other. It will be rejected by the Australian worker unless that process is gradual. We acknowledge the merits in the alternative model, but we warn against a hasty transition.

Do the Liberal and National parties really want enterprise based industrial relations or do they want something else? The current leadership espouses compromise and negotiation. I attribute both of those qualities to Senator Chaney's position on industrial relations. However, the New Right is deregulationist to the point of hysteria, as exemplified by the President of the Liberal Party and the assorted New Right ideologues who have taken over the Liberal Party's policy making mechanisms. In other words, will moderation prevail?

What about deregulation of the labour market? At worst-and we must consider the worst proposition, the worst possible outcomes from the alternative model-the coalition's industrial relations policy stands for complete deregulation of the labour market. It would phase out the Industrial Relations Commission and eliminate the principle of minimum rates of pay. The strongest unions, whose labour services are in short supply, would extract the biggest pay rises. People working in unskilled areas where labour is plentiful would be forced to take the lowest rate for their work with no minimum awards. Their wages would drop. That is a possible worst outcome from the alternative model.

Senator Chaney raised the possibility of Australia becoming a banana republic. Of course, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) cited that possibility some years ago and Senator Chaney has repeated it today. Another of the Opposition's aims is to put a time limit of six months on the payment of unemployment benefit. If it succeeded in that, as well as in deregulating the labour market, we would fast become a real banana republic-a country in which 30 per cent of the population would be forced into pseudo-slavery. They would be forced to work for whatever pay was available with no social security safety net and nowhere to live. This would be especially pertinent in my State of New South Wales where Sydney home prices are now beyond the wildest dreams of the bulk of the population. This would create a class of cheap servants willing to work ridiculous hours for food and shelter. This is where the New Right would lead us. This is what it would expect a Liberal-National Party industrial relations Minister to implement. That is the worst possible outcome, and we should be considering the worst possible outcome.

We should be encouraging Australians to work together. Deregulation of the labour market would not achieve that. The union movement would simply revolt and we would revert to a situation similar to that of the last days of the Fraser Government, with wage explosions, industrial unrest, increasing unemployment and soaring inflation. Those were the characteristics of the last days of the Fraser Government. Those were the characteristics which typified a period when we had a government which was advocating this alternate model.

Let me turn briefly to the question of foreign debt and living standards. Ordinary Australian wage earners, pensioners, home buyers, rural producers and small businessmen have already experienced a decline in living standards through the expenditure cutting and high interest rate policies of this Government. We do not deny that. The Australian Democrats have acknowledged and cited that over and over again in this place. We are told that Australians must suffer to reduce our foreign debt. But whose foreign debt is it? The private sector debt accounts for well over half of our level of foreign indebtedness. The Bonds, Elliotts and Murdochs of our society borrow overseas and ordinary Australians are forced to tighten their belts because, we are told, we are borrowing too much. We are not borrowing too much; they are borrowing too much. Those who borrow overseas should be asked to pay for it, not the pensioners and home buyers. Currently, foreign borrowings by Australian companies to finance takeovers are subsidised by taxpayers. We do not have to wreak havoc with our industrial relations system to resolve these problems. We can simply disallow the tax deductions to companies which borrow overseas to finance takeovers.

We are simply citing the fact that there are dangers inherent in the alternate model. Senator Chaney's proposition really says that it should be a matter of public importance that we implement the Opposition's industrial relations policy. We believe that it is a matter of public importance that this chamber and the Australian people are warned about the inherent dangers in both of them. We see the merits and demerits of both sides of the argument.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —At the conclusion of Senator Button's remarks he asked-Senator McLean echoed the question-what this matter of public importance debate directed at the Government was all about. I understand Senator Button's state of bemusement because that seems to characterise his general state of mind these days. It was not so long ago-only a few weeks-that Senator Button was being interviewed on the Face to Face television program. After being cross-examined on what his industrial policies have achieved over the past few years he simply did not say very much. When he was asked how he would go about it if he had it all to do again, I felt rather sorry for Senator Button because he simply spread his hands apart and said, `I don't know'. If Senator Button does not know what this matter of public importance is all about-unfortunately he has left the chamber-I will, vicariously, direct his attention to some of the things that it is about.

SPEECH.PARA: Today is Budget day. This will probably, although not certainly, be this Government's last Budget. Since the Budget is, after all, the single most important economic statement that any government makes in any given 12 months, as a rule, it will therefore probably be this Government's last opportunity to address Australia's fundamental-I emphasise the word `fundamental'-economic problems.

As Senator Chaney quite rightly said, if we go around this country and talk to average Australians and some of the small businessmen to whom, apparently, Senator Button does not talk-he talks to the great corporate chieftains-and we ask people what they feel about Australia, the almost universal response is that they are very worried about the future of this country. Depending upon their family circumstances they may be very worried about the future of their children. There is a state of growing concern characterised most pithily by people's concern about the extraordinary explosion of foreign indebtedness. In the last six years between March 1983 and March 1989 the foreign debt of Australians-that is, governments, private corporations and private individuals-has risen in net terms from $23 billion to nearly $104 billion. A great many people do not know those sorts of figures but they do understand, because they can see the evidence all around them, that this country is sliding into a morass of foreign debt at a frightening pace. They can also see-this is sometimes even more directly visible; Senator Chaney also referred to this and I believe it is particularly true of my own state of Queensland-the accelerating pace of foreign ownership of Australia.

I mention this matter not in order to indulge in any sort of xenophobia about foreign investment in this country; on the contrary. Yet it is a matter of very great concern to Australians, who can see it happening around them, that somehow or other we are losing control of this country; we are losing control of our future. People may not understand all this economists' jargon, which, I must confess, I still sometimes fall into the error of using. They understand that when a family lives beyond its means at the pace at which this country has been living beyond its means under this Government for the past six years, and when that family accumulates debts in proportion to the magnitude of those that Australia has already accumulated-goodness knows, we will have accumulated another $15 billion before the next election at the pace things are going-when a family is in that situation and is being forced to sell off some of its assets, as Australia has been doing during the life of this Government, they know from their own observation of families that they have seen in those unfortunate circumstances that it is increasingly difficult to get themselves out of that situation. So they are concerned about the future of this country and about our ability to control that future and whether this control will not simply be taken out of our hands.

When we come right down to fundamentals and discuss this with people in a commonsense way and with not too much economic jargon, everybody will agree in the end that it all stems from our fundamental inability to pay our way in the world. Our deficit in our balance of payments stems from the fact that we are not competitive. Our productive game is just not good enough. Our productivity performance-that is a bit of jargon, I suppose-the efficiency of our operating processes in our factories and other areas of production is simply dismal.

When we see the Budget Papers tonight we will ask what this Budget will do to redress that situation. Although we have not seen the documents as yet I suspect that the answer will be nothing. If the press is to be believed, we will probably get some words as to how Mr Keating is going to restructure the Industries Assistance Commission, the Industries Commission and half a dozen other bodies to add to his own power base, and this new body will be given a task of reporting on this and that-but it will be just words, verbiage. It will not be actually doing anything to repair the parlous situation in which we find ourselves.

If ever there was one major area that is crying out for reform it is the area to which the matter of public importance referred to by Senator Chaney relates-namely, the whole structure of our trade union movement in this country. During this century Australia has moved from being a country which at the beginning of the twentieth century was the richest country in the world in per capita terms. People in this country enjoyed the highest living standards and the highest income on average of any country in the world. Because we were a more egalitarian country-a matter with which I agree-our working people were even more ahead of their counterparts in other countries than those average figures would imply. What has happened in the past 89 years to move us to a situation in which we are no longer enjoying that admirable pre-eminence, in which we have declined more or less continually relative to other countries, in which we are sliding back to seventeenth, eighteenth, nineteenth or twentieth position in the world, depending on precisely which figures we look at?

We are well back in the field of nations, having been in the very first rank 100 years ago. Although I do not have time in these brief remarks to develop this thesis to the length it deserves, the truth is that we have throughout this period been burdened with a system for the determination of wages and other conditions of employment as well as a system of trade union organisation which is a product of the nineteenth century. The craft union dominated trade union organisation brought to us largely from Britain is a product of the nineteenth century which increasingly is totally unfitted and inappropriate to the problems of the twentieth century, let alone the twenty-first century, which we are only 10 or 11 years away from entering.

If Senator Button does not understand why this matter of public importance on this subject is directed to this Government today then all I can say is that he has not understood that basic point. It is about time that he and the Government he represents did. I accept what Senator Button said about one or two specific instances which he was able to cite-including the Southern Aluminium instance, which has not been finalised. They are precisely the forms of enterprise union to which the Opposition's industrial relations policy is directed and to which Senator Chaney was directing his remarks. Senator Button, in responding to that, said, `We the Government are already moving in that direction'. If we continue at that sort of snail's pace, which is the product of this Government's performance, it will be the twenty-second century before we get there, and by that time Australians will not be running this country.

Last week we saw what I can only describe as an irresponsible national wage case decision by the new Industrial Relations Commission-a decision which that body and the Government say will produce an increase in average wages this year of 6 1/2 per cent, but which every independent private commentator whom I have noticed remarking on the subject has indicated is likely to produce an increase of about 7 1/2 to 8 per cent. Why do I call that decision irresponsible? I call it irresponsible because the Commission noted, before moving to provide these awards, Australia's parlous economic state. The Commission said that in the light of that situation:
There are substantial economic grounds for rejecting any notion of wage increases at the present time.

Notwithstanding those words, the Industrial Relations Commission, having made its bow in the direction of what we might call economic propriety, then proceeded to move to economic irresponsibility with the decision that it handed down.

Only the day after that decision was handed down the Australian Bureau of Statistics produced a paper entitled `Australian National Accounts March Quarter 1989: Gross Product Employment and Hours Worked', which said that labour productivity estimates continue to show very little change from the 1984-85 base year. That is to say, the real product per hour worked per worker employed has hardly changed over the past five years. What a record! What a performance by the present Government! How does that compare with overseas countries? We all know how it compares but I do not have time to go into it in detail. I used an analogy a moment ago of a family living beyond its means. How does a family that is in that situation deal with it? As we all know, there are only two ways: one is to pull in the belt; the other is to lift its productive game to bring more income into the household.

Tonight I suppose we will have the product in Mr Keating's Budget of a process of telling people to pull in their belts. For some time now Mr Keating has been forcing Australians to pull in their belts. He has been doing that through exorbitantly high interests rates. We hear a lot about 17 per cent home loan rates; but the rates being paid by small businessmen, which in many ways are more important in terms of the productivity of this country, are 22 or 23 per cent, not 17 per cent. Mr Keating's view, however, is that the private sector should pull in its belt. He also believes the State governments should pull in their belts. He has told them that they will get less in funds this year. We will see how much sign there is in the Budget Speech tonight of the Government pulling in its belt. I predict confidently that tonight the Government will not be showing any sign of recognition that there is another and better alternative: lifting our productive game. It is that better alternative, through the recognition of the fundamental interdependence of the interests of employers and employees as reflected in enterprise unions, to which Senator Chaney's remarks were properly directed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate this afternoon is debating a matter of public importance submitted by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Chaney:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for the Government to adopt a new approach to industrial relations which is enterprise-based, to encourage Australians to work together more productively to reduce our foreign debt and to stop the slide in living standards.

These are commendable objectives but there is a fatal flaw in the matter put forward by Senator Chaney, as was pointed out by the Leader of the Government in this place, Senator Button, when he asked, `Why direct it to us? Why direct it to the Government?'. The Government is acutely aware of the sentiments contained in the matter of public importance and is now actively working to achieve those objectives.

TALK.START.PARA: —When did you start?

—We started on achieving office in 1983. We have continued our effort under the banner of the prices and incomes accord and agreement between the Government and the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) and its affiliated bodies.
—That's why it has not occurred.

—It has continued to this day. It is continuing apace, as any of us who get out and talk with people, be they small businessmen, large enterprises or the workers in those enterprises, know. The change is with us. It is happening apace. In some establishments it is happening very fast but in other establishments it is happening not quite so fast. But have no fear; change is happening in Australia today. It is most certainly and most decidedly happening in the industrial relations area. We need to give this matter of public importance some attention and to examine the ramifications not only for the workers in industry, those that are producing the wealth of the nation, but also for Australians as a whole, those that depend on the welfare benefits that come from the taxation paid by workers.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Chaney gave an estimate of 800,000 work places in Australia today, an estimate which I hold him to. He initially said that there were between 800,000 and one million work places. It is quite conceivable that in a completely deregulated labour market a single union could emerge in each of those enterprises. One of the great cries in Australia today is that there are far too many unions, a sentiment that is agreed with by Labor senators and one that is supported by the Government. Its actions in bringing in the new industrial relations legislation last year is proof of that. How could we move from a position of having 300-odd unions to one of having nearly one million single unions? It is absolutely crazy! However there may be some merit in it for those who hold great influence within the Liberal Party of Australia today. Senator Button alluded to that. He talked about the New Right influences. In recent months we have seen a spate of preselection results from a number of individuals who were pre-eminent in the industrial relations sphere if not on a hands-on basis, as some of them would have liked, then certainly as speakers and writers on the subject of industrial relations. I refer to people like David Kemp, Peter Costello, Rod Kemp, Ian McLachlan and our own Senator Stone, the previous speaker, who has aspirations to move to the other place. We have also heard about Charles Copeman. Charles Copeman came to prominence in the area of industrial relations because of his involvement in an enterprise in the Pilbara region of Western Australia. What was then Cliffs Robe River Iron Associates was taken over and became Robe River Iron Associates, an iron ore mining operation operating out of Pannawonica and Cape Lambert. We saw industrial relations turned on its head. We are seeing it and witnessing it today in Western Australia. It demonstrates the ramifications of a single `union enterprise' thinking.

That happened some years ago, but let us see what has happened in recent months. I just happened to have in my drawer in the chamber on the first day back after the recess an article that was printed in the West Australian of Tuesday, 23 May 1989. The headline states, `Paymistress quits after refusing to drive truck'. A paymistress is presumably a person with secretarial skills, perhaps one who operates a computer in an office, and such a person was told to drive a truck. Those honourable senators who have visited iron ore mines would appreciate the size of those trucks. This lady, Miss Sainsbury, was instructed to drive a truck. She was an employee of the enterprise and as such was subject to the directives of her master, Robe River-one of the leading New Right companies in this country. Such a company, along with Mudginberri and so forth, can be held up as an example of what would happen if the Opposition were in government.

A few days later, on 26 May, another article appeared in the West Australian. I notice my colleague, Senator Foreman, has fairly rapidly left the chamber. He must have known what headline I would next refer to. The article was headed, `Foreman told to get out of town'. In part, the article states:
A mine foreman has been given a week to get out of town after protesting against the forced resignation of Pannawonica paymistress Andrea Sainsbury.

So Robe River Iron Associates hits not only the hands-on workers, but also the supervisors-an enormous change. The individual who is credited with taking most of the action and with being the driving force behind the happenings at Robe River is one Charles Copeman.

TALK.START.PARA: —Soon to be a member of this Parliament, too.

—I would doubt that very much. I note for Senator Crichton-Browne's benefit that Senator Stone in his contribution was not at all confident that tonight would be the last Labor Budget. SPEECH.PARA: A couple of days after the leadership change I had to stand in for Fred Chaney at a Killara Liberal Party lunch. TALK.START.PARA: —It would solve that if you had just one union in each enterprise. Let's look at the next century, not the last century.

—I ask Senator Lewis not to interfere because if he does I will start using words like 5 per cent, which we probably would use in the next century. But that is another argument. I hope that Senator Lewis too will refer to that. To give Senator Chaney credit, he mentioned the current conflict with the airline pilots and the grab that they are making for what is recognised by the vast majority of Australians of all political persuasions as a grab for excessive wages. SPEECH.PARA: Senator Stone made great play about the size of our foreign debt. That is a worry to all, including the Government. The majority of the money that has been brought into Australia, which it now costs the Australian community to service, has been brought in to finance takeovers, mostly unproductive takeovers. We have had debates in this place about that matter.

Senator Stone also made the point that the level of foreign debt has grown over a period of years. He spoke about the decline in the standard of living of Australians, that we have gone from being at the top of the tree 89 years ago to being now at position No. 17, 18 or 19, depending on which graph one looks at.

In reply to that comment, I make the point that for the majority of the 89 years that he referred to, this nation was governed by conservative governments. For 30 of the last 40 years we were governed by conservative governments, the last of which left us in an awful mess that has taken us many years to try to overcome.

Senator McLean made a point about `divide and conquer' or `divide and rule'. That is something that pervades the industrial relations system in Australia. The industrial relations system is and has been structured as an adversarial system, but that is slowly being overcome. Despite the fact that the adversarial system is in place at the moment, there are many fine examples in Australian industry of employers and employees working together hand in glove-at different degrees and with different results, but it is happening. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a matter of public importance in these terms:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for the Government to adopt a new approach to industrial relations which is enterprise-based, to encourage Australians to work together more productively to reduce our foreign debt and to stop the slide in living standards.

The Australian Labor Party has now been in government for 6 1/2 years-during 6 1/2 years of world prosperity. There is now no world recession or nationwide drought, as was the case during the last years of the Fraser Government; there is world prosperity. During this period, in recent years in particular, Australia has had high commodity prices, high volumes of sales of our basic commodities, and very much increased tourism. Under this Government there has been a substantial fall in the value of the Australian dollar. All of these opportunities have been wasted because it is now clear that this Government's policies have failed miserably. Since this Government came into office our foreign debt has increased from $23 billion to about $104 billion, an increase of about 400 per cent, a figure which is growing every year by a massive rate-at the rate of $17.75 billion or thereabouts this year, and at an estimated $20 billion next year, because that is the level of the current account deficit.

Similarly, people from the United Kingdom and the United States and foreign companies operating in Australia now find that it is cheap to buy valuable Australian assets because of the great deficit which this country faces every year. We have to borrow that amount of money from overseas or sell assets to people overseas to make up the deficit. This is now causing much concern in the Australian community.

What is wrong? The simple answer is that we are not producing enough goods of the kind that people in Australia and overseas want to buy. We are simply not producing enough. We cannot expect to get much more from our commodities being sold overseas; we cannot expect to get much more from our tourist dollar-although we are hoping to get a little more, undoubtedly. Clearly we have to make up the shortfall in our manufacturing industries. Companies have gone offshore rather than continue to produce in Australia. I quote in this regard the Hon. Joe Thompson, a former secretary of the Vehicle Builders Union. I am not quoting an employer; I am quoting a former secretary of a trade union. In a recent IPA Review article Joe Thompson said:

. . . over the past 20 years, substantial sections of our manufacturing industry have ceased operating here and moved offshore . . . Much of this has been caused by what can only be termed the sabotage of our manufacturing industry by those unions which have exploited the present industrial relations system for short-term advantage.
He went on to say:
Without a doubt, we have the most self-destructive system in the free world . . .

What has happened in Australia is that, as a result of the system introduced to suit the conditions of last century, Australian productivity improvement has been consistently below the average for major industrialised countries. We are simply not keeping pace. Since 1985 under this Government productivity has edged up at a miserable 0.4 per cent a year as the output per unit of labour. We are now at a stage where a Minister as senior as the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) is prepared to concede that the Government has got it wrong. The key element of the Government's third term agenda . . .
