QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 25 May 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are there any dangers of chemical residues being used as a key non-tariff barrier to international trade?
(2) Is it the intention of the Government to sign the GATT Standards Code on chemical residues; if not, why not?
(3) Is it the intention of the Government to adopt all the FAO Codex Alimentarius standards; if not, why not?
(4) Are there any dangers to Australian farm exports should the Government decline to sign the GATT standards and adopt the FAO standards?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Potential has always existed for chemical residues to be used as non-tariff barriers to trade. All countries have the sovereign right to set limits on the levels of chemical residues that will be permitted in products imported into their territories. The potential thus exists for countries to set unreasonable and unjustifiable levels for chemical residues or unreasonable or unjustifiable testing requirements. Of course, countries may voluntarily restrict their freedom of action through international agreements or through adopting internationally agreed standards.

The need to balance Governments' desire to set standards, against the potential for arbitrary trade restrictions, is acknowledged in Article XX (b) of the GATT which recognises the right of all Contracting Parties to apply measures, as necessary, to protect human, animal or plant life or health but makes it clear that such measures should not be used as disguised restrictions on international trade. Also, Article III of the GATT provides that regulations should not be applied to imported or domestic products so as to afford protection to domestic production.

Australia is seeking to ensure this question of balance in the use of sanitary and phytosanitary barriers is addressed in the Agricultural Negotiations Group in the current Round of Multilateral Trade Negotiations, the Uruguay Round. The negotiations aim to facilitate international trade taking into account the work of the international organisations, such as the joint FAO/WHO Codex Alimentarius Commission, which establish appropriate and acceptable chemical residue limits.

(2) The Agreement on Technical Barriers to trade (popularly known as the Standards Code) was negotiated during the last Round (Tokyo Round) of Multilateral Trade Negotiations. One objective of the Code is to encourage the development of international standards and certification systems.

The Government is presently liaising with State/Territory Governments to enable Australia to become a signatory to the Code. Earlier this year a draft National Agreement on Standards Accreditation and Quality (NASAQ) was considered by Federal/State and New Zealand Ministers meeting as the Australian Industry and Technology Council (AITC).

One of the provisions of NASAQ is that, upon its signature, Australia would give notice of its intention to join the Standards Code. AITC Ministers were well disposed towards NASAQ and agreed that the principles it contained constituted a good basis for negotiations.

It is expected that the Agreement, including the provision on the Standards Code, will be adopted at the next meeting of the AITC in October 1989. It is also expected that the procedural aspects of implementing Australia's rights and obligations in acceding to the Standards Code will be discussed between Commonwealth Departments and with the States/Territories in the near future.

(3) Australia is a member of, and plays an active role in, the work of the joint FAO/WHO Codex Alimentarius Commission, particularly in its subsidiary Committees on pesticide residues, residues of veterinary drugs in food, and food additives and contaminants. The work of these Committees is, through consensus, to establish maximum residue limits in foods entering international trade. Australia sees the standards set by these three Codex Committees as one of the main international mechanisms for preventing residues from being used as non-tariff technical barriers to trade.

The Commonwealth Government is keen to adopt Codex standards as it sees them as a means of facilitating food exports. To date, however, this has not been possible because responsibility for the administration of domestic food standards presently rests with the States/Territories. Further, acceptance depends on uniform adoption by all States/Territories.

Acceptance of a Codex standard makes incorporation of the standard into a country's domestic legislation obligatory. As a result, much work has been done to provide for the adoption of the Uniform Food Standards Code into the food legislation of each State and Territory of the Commonwealth.

To facilitate the adoption of Codex standards, the Australian Food Standards Committee aims to align national standards, as far as practicable, with Codex standards. Recent emphasis on this aspect has led to a much closer alignment of national standards with those of Codex than in the past.

(4) As the above answers indicate, the GATT Standards Code and the Codex Commission have different but complementary mandates. The Code does not itself set standards; rather it sets rules and procedures to ensure that technical regulations or standards adopted for reasons related to safety, health, quarantine and consumer or environmental protection do not create unreasonable barriers to trade. Membership of the Code would require Australia to use appropriate international standards as the basis of technical regulations and standards; which would include the international food standards, codes and guidelines prepared by the Codex Commission.

The Government considers that membership of the Code will assist its efforts to achieve improved access to world markets for Australian exports facing unreasonably restrictive or discriminatory standards.

By comparison, the Codex Commission prepares international food standards, codes, and guidelines in order to facilitate international trade through the removal of non-tariff technical barriers caused by different national food standards.

Participation in Codex enables us to provide input into the development of standards and requirements with which our food exports usually have to comply. All of Australia's significant trading partners are members of Codex and, given that Australia needs to meet the standards imposed by other countries which import Australian products, exporting will be easier if Australian food standards are the same as those in the countries to which we export. For this reason, the Federal Government is working actively to enable Australia to become a signatory to the standards of the joint FAO/WHO Codex Alimentarius Commission.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 29 May 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that construction costs for process industry developments in Australia are one-third to one-half higher than in other industrialised countries?

(2) Given that Australia's relatively poor labour productivity and efficiency record is one of the main reasons for this higher cost structure, what action, if any, does the Government propose to take to make it possible for major process industry investment project to achieve the productivity gains necessary to become internationally competitive?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) My Department is not aware of any comprehensive and objective comparative construction cost data on Australian process construction projects.

A soon to be released report commissioned by the Victorian Department of Industry, Technology and Resources, has examined the predictability of Australian engineering construction project performance against initial project budgets and schedules.
at least 3/4 of Australian project owners regarded the cost and time performance of their projects as good.

the primary cause of poor cost performance on private sector projects was monetary fluctuation through exchange rate variation and escalation change. This reflects the high level of change in the economy during the study's time frame.
workforce productivity was on par or better than budget assessments in 95% of projects.

The study also compared a sample of UK and Australian projects with respect to performance against cost and time targets. The comparison showed that UK projects perform more predictably to cost and time targets than Australian projects. However, these figures do not represent a comparison of the standard of productivity or the relative economy of engineering construction between countries.

Preliminary results of two studies commissioned by the Australian Manufacturing Council show that capital costs per tonne of annual capacity for establishing a zinc or titanium dioxide processing plant in Australia were directly comparable to costs in the four or five most important competitor countries, including Canada and Singapore.

(2) The Victorian Government report I referred to earlier, identifies a range of areas where the competitiveness of Australian engineering construction project capability can be improved and where Australia can become a more competitive location for geographically mobile projects. These include:
a national industry council be formed from representatives of owners, contractors, unions and governments to facilitate restructuring of the industry
a national construction award be established
industry and government examine effects of government policies on projects costs
training for the engineering construction industry should be reviewed and further developed by industry and government
the industry seek joint union-employer agreement to eliminate inefficient work practices
Australian research into project industry matters be coordinated by a properly constituted national body
research be undertaken into the comparative performance of countries which compete with Australia for project investment.

The Construction Industry Council, the prime tripartite industry advisory body for the building and construction industry and chaired by the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business, is to take on responsibility for the analysis and implementation by industry and government of the report's findings.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 29 May 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In view of the fact that the Royal Norwegian Air Force (RNAF) has lost 11 out of its 72 F16 aircraft through accidents, that this represents an attrition rate of 15 per cent, and the Inspector-General of the RNAF attributes this to `a critical lack of experienced senior pilots', and that if the Royal Australian Air Force were to sustain a similar attrition rate, we could lose 10 F/A-18's in the next 5 to 6 years, each F/A-18 costing approximately $41 million, and that the RAAF is still losing pilots at a high rate, does the Minister take any warning from RNAF's experience, and does he consider that it would be better to increase pilot salaries now to keep them in service or to lose $41 million-a-copy aircraft later.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has provided the following answer to the honourable senator question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Royal Norwegian Air Force F-16 aircraft accident rate is high. Any comparison, however, between RNAF and RAAF accident rates could be misleading. The RNAF's modus operandi and operating environment are so different to those of the RAAF that a valid comparison of RNAF F-16 and RAAF Hornet accident rates cannot be made.

(2) Since the introduction of the Hornet to RAAF service in 1985, the RAAF has lost one aircraft. The pilot of this aircraft was a student on the Hornet conversion course hence inexperienced on type. He was nevertheless an experienced Mirage pilot with some 1 000 flying hours.

(3) The accident rate for all RAAF aircraft for FY87/88 was 8.3 accidents per 100 000 flying hours compared to a 12 year average of 5.4 per 100 000 hours. For FY88/89 the accident rate is presently running at a significantly lower rate than the long term average. The Hornet accident rate, one loss since introduction to service, means very little so early in the aircraft's service life but can be described as below the traditional accident rate experienced during the introduction of a new fighter aircraft.

(4) Increases in pilot salaries are determined by the Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal (DFRT). The DFRT is required to base its deliberations on current Industrial Relations Commission guidelines. The following inducements for pilots to remain in the RAAF are now in force:
(a) Flying allowance was substantially increased in 1988, from $4529 to $11330 per annum (for a Squadron Leader employed in a flying post).

(b) The Pilot Retention Bonus (PRB) has been offered to 242 RAAF pilots. With effect 6 June 1989, 117 pilots have accepted the PRB, and are thus committed to serve for a six-year period. Further offers of the PRB will be made in FY89/90. The PRB scheme is due for Government review in 1992.

(c) The Aircrew Specialization Option is now available to selected RAAF pilots. The scheme provides continued employment in flying posts for a period of five years, and aims to improve retention of aircrew and increase experience levels on operational flying units. The scheme will build to its mature complement of fifty Flight Lieutenants and ten Squadron Leaders over the next five years.
(d) Pilots, along with other RAAF officers, may receive further salary increases as a result of the present ADF study into a wage case based on work value principles.

(5) The inducements identified for pilots to remain in the RAAF, combined with an increase in Return of Service Obligation for pilot's course to eight years, should result in a long term improvement in pilot experience levels. The current reduced levels of experience in the RAAF are undesirable, but posting and personnel management policies have been reviewed to ensure that the average experience in operational squadrons/units is sufficient to maintain flying safety standards.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 31 May 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did Professor Stephen R. Leeder, Director of the Department of Community Medicine at the Westmead Hospital in Sydney, write a letter to the Commissioner for Taxation on 16 May 1989.
(2) Did his letter complain about failings in the process for the issuing of a tax file number to his mother.
(3) Is there any logical answer to the complaints he raises.
(4) What action is being taken to correct the failings in the system to which Professor Leeder has referred.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Commissioner of Taxation has no record in any of his offices of the receipt of a letter from Professor Leeder.
However, I understand that the letter dealt with difficulties likely to be encountered by elderly or disabled people who wish to apply for a tax file number.

In order to protect the integrity of the Tax File Number System, it is imperative that adequate proof of identity be required on application for a tax file number. When compiling lists of acceptable proof of identity documents, the Commissioner included as large a variety of documents and combinations of documents as he could, in order to ensure that people who did not have the usual ones readily available, could choose some other acceptable combination of documents.
Where people genuinely have a problem obtaining the necessary number of documents, the Commissioner will assist by accepting some other forms of proof of identity.

The Commissioner contracted with Australia Post to receive tax file number applications on behalf of the Tax Office and to sight proof of identity documents as a service to the public to make applying for a tax file number more convenient. The training of Post Office staff was conducted internally by Australia Post and there have been some problems with staff's understanding of the procedures. The Commissioner is undertaking a review of the system of lodging applications for tax file numbers at Post Offices and of the training of Post Office staff in administering the system.
People who are unable to visit a Post Office or a Tax Office can send their application and their proof of identity documents to the Tax Office by mail.

Finally, I believe the Professor complained of difficulty in getting through to the Tax Office's Tax File Number Hotline. The strategy employed in managing the Hotline was to begin with a small facility and then to increase it in proportion to the volume of calls being received. Around 1 April, when all existing employees were brought into the Tax File Number System, the volume of calls increased beyond expectations and it took some two or three weeks to recruit the necessary number of operators to deal with the level of calls. This, combined with industrial action being taken by unions at that time, caused some inconvenience to callers for a short period of time. By 30 June, the volume of calls being received by the Hotline had decreased to such an extent that maintaining the Hotline was no longer justified and it was discontinued.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 7 June 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: Following the reorganisation of the Defence Science and Technology Organisation, the Systems Research Laboratory SRL in Salisbury, South Australia is divided into 3 major laboratories-
(a) what are the economic and scientific benefits of this tripartite division;
(b) what has been the total cost of reorganising the SRL; and
(c) could a breakdown of these costs be provided.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: I am informed that the question refers to the restructuring, as part of the wider DSTO reorganisation, of the three laboratories located at DSTO, Salisbury. These laboratories had themselves grown from the Weapons Research Establishments set up in the 1950s. Prior to the reorganisation the three laboratories were:
The reorganisation of the DSTO was announced on October 12, 1987 by the then Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, Mrs Ros Kelly.
The announcement advised that the reorganisation was designed to meet three principal objectives:
Responding to priorities identified in the Defence White Paper;
Streamlining the transition of work from DSTO research into industry; and
Further developing Australia's expertise in critical defence technologies.
To achieve these objectives, three out of five DSTO laboratories now have significantly changed functions.

At Salisbury the new Surveillance Research Laboratory comprising much of the former Electronics Research Laboratory concentrates on electromagnetic surveillance, but with greater effort on over-the-horizon radar.
The new look Electronics Research Laboratory has main thrusts in Command and Control, Information Technology.

Communications and Electronic Warfare. It includes some functions of the former Advanced Engineering Laboratory whose remaining engineering capabilities have been integrated into the other DSTO Laboratories. Less extensive changes occurred at the Weapons Systems Laboratory in Salisbury and Sydney.
With this information by way of background, the responses to the questions posed are as follows:

(a) The economic and scientific benefits are those outlined in the principal objectives. To these may be added an increase on the DSTO capacity for research through a gradual adjustment of staff profiles, increasing the proportion of scientists and engineers by a reduction in supporting and workshop staff. DSTO is now able to provide more cost-effective support for the Australian Defence Organisation and increase the transfer of technology to industry to the benefit of the Australian economy as a whole.

(b) and (c) DSTO is a dynamic organisation that is continually adjusting its priorities and structure to meet Australia's defence needs. The 1987 reorganisation brought together many changes that would have occurred over a period of time including some that affected other DSTO establishments in Melbourne and Sydney. Consequently it is not possible to isolate costs to the Salisbury laboratories. However, the cost of the total reorganisation of DSTO, including the laboratories at Salisbury, has been contained within DSTO's annual budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 5 April 1989 (Hansard, page 971), Senator Patterson asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Is it a fact that only one Medicare schedule fee now applies to cover maternal confinements, regardless of such variable factors as the number of antenatal consultations or the method of delivery? Did the present Government change the Medicare schedule in August 1987 so that only one schedule fee of $425 now covers all births? Can the Minister advise why the Government believes that the skills and time involved in a straightforward birth are the same as those for a complicated forceps delivery or a caesarean section. Is it the intention of the Government that obstetricians should be forced to change their clinical practices through a system of financial disincentives? Is the Government aware that consumers who have caesarean sections or other forms of surgical intervention in delivery have, in most cases, no choice in the matter and, therefore, can be faced with substantial unscheduled out of pocket expenses in giving birth? The obstetrics items in the Medicare Benefits Schedule were restructured from 1 August 1987 in line with a recommendation of the Medicare Benefits Review (Layton) Committee that a comprehensive item be introduced to cover antenatal care, confinement with delivery by any means (including Caesarean section) and post-natal care. The comprehensive fee was introduced on medical advice that it was in the best interests of both mother and baby. It was unanimously recommended by the Layton Committee-two of whose five members were senior nominees of the Australian Medical Association (AMA)-after extensive consultation with the Royal Australian College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists and the Federal AMA Coordinating Committee of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists. The current Schedule fee for this comprehensive item when performed by a specialist obstetrician is $425.

Separate items have been retained for use when the comprehensive item is not appropriate (e.g. when obstetric care is provided by more than one medical practitioner), for attendances involving antenatal complications and for a number of other additional services which might be required.

The schedule fee of $425 is substantially higher than the previous fee for care in a normal pregnancy, labour and delivery and recognises the proportion of labours in which more complex procedures are needed. Instead of the doctor using add-on items for these extra procedures, they are allowed for in the new comprehensive fee. The restructuring removed the financial incentive for doctors to intervene in the natural birthing process and removed the multiple patient gap payments that existed where separate fees were raised for individual component services.

The obstetric items in the Medicare Benefits Schedule have been the subject of continuing review since the restructuring and a number of amendments have been implemented. The next meeting of the Consultative Group on Obstetrics and Gynaecology, which is scheduled for 18 July 1989, will be devoted to discussion of obstetric matters. This liaison group, which comprises representatives from the Royal Australian College of Obstetrics and Gynaecology, the Australian Medical Association, the Department of Community Services and Health and the Health Insurance Commission, forms part of the Government's consultative process which permits input from the medical profession on Medicare Benefits Schedule reviews.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Government Changes to Financial Administration Requirements

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 3 May 1989 (Hansard, page 1681), Senator Watson asked a question without notice about the Government's changes in financial administration requirements. The following information is provided in answer to the honourable senator's question.

ANSWER.PARA: In its Policy Paper on Budget Reform (April 1984) the Government stated the objectives of its reforms as being about:
improving the processes of decision making on budget priorities by the Government itself;
improving the information base and processes for public and parliamentary scrutiny of the budget and of the subsequent implementation of programs funded from the budget; and
upgrading the financial management of programs in all Government agencies.

A comprehensive package of financial management improvements is now in place under the broad heading of the Financial Management Improvement Program (FMIP). Progress in implementation of the FMIP by departments was reported on recently in the 1988 FMIP Report, copies of which are available through the Australian Government Publishing Service.

Key elements of the FMIP have been the adoption by departments of management systems which assist managers to focus on results and the development of improved accountability arrangements, under which the emphasis is shifting from accounting for stewardship of resources to a concern with achieving results. Program Management and Budgeting (PMB) has been the primary vehicle for bringing about these changes.

Among other things, the PMB framework requires departments to set program objectives which reflect the desired outcomes of Government policy, to be able to account for resource inputs against those programs, to develop performance information systems which will enable informed judgements to be made about both the effectiveness of programs in achieving their stated objectives and the efficiency with which they do it, and finally to report these matters to the Parliament. All departments and budget funded agencies have now adopted PMB.

The principal vehicle through which departments and agencies report on their performance is the Explanatory Notes provided to Parliament at Budget time. (Other documents, notably Annual Reports and Budget Paper No. 3, also play an important role in this respect.) Since 1987-88 the Explanatory Notes have set out program objectives, the resources allocated to programs, the results achieved in the previous year and expectations for the coming year. Recognizing the importance of the Explanatory Notes in this format the Government has incorporated them among the formal budget documentation as Budget Related Papers.
In short, Parliament is now receiving the sort of information referred to in the question. This is a great advancement on the level of information provided, say five years ago.

Departments and agencies are progressively improving the quality of the performance information they are able to provide. The process of review and refinement is seen as on-going, responding to improvements in performance information systems within departments and routine processes of policy adjustment.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 5 June 1989 (Hansard, page 3306), Senator Puplick asked me a question without notice concerning the alleged environmentally damaging consequences of draining the Guthega Reservoir earlier that day by the Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Authority. I can now provide the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The drainage was carried out as part of a normal operational procedure to calibrate instrumentation under zero load conditions installed to monitor dam load under varying conditions necessary to determine the integrity and safety of the dam. Previous draining (eg 1984 and 1985) had not adversely affected the Snowy River environment downstream and this, together with monthly test operation of the dam's river outlet gate, suggested that any silt residues would be low.

The Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Authority does not seek clearance for operational decisions from its Minister or any other Minister. Consultations on environmental issues with NSW officials occur on an on-going basis and, on this occasion, they expressed some concerns. As a result, NSW officials accepted an invitation to attend the drainage and sample the released water. Enquiries of NSW National Parks and Wildlife Service officials also indicated that no platypus colonies were present on the stretch of river involved.

Most of the water was drained via the pressure tunnel in the normal turbining process. Only 170 million litres (or about 10%) remained for release through the dam's river outlet gates. This water was released in an environmentally sensitive way at a controlled rate of between 20 to 30 cubic metres per second (about 1/10th of the flood capacity of the river) but nevertheless, as planned, the quality of the water was monitored by Authority and NSW officials. Drainage, calibration and commencement of refilling the reservoir took less than one day.

Monitoring has shown that there is no silt in the river bed. While there were a few millimetres of silt deposits above normal water level, additional water was released on 9 June to flush some of the remaining silt, with further flushes to occur as necessary with the snowmelt in the spring. There have been no apparent effects on fish or other fauna.

It is correct that the Authority is not obliged to comply with NSW environmental legislation. However, the Authority is sensitive to environmental issues and fully recognises the need to act in a caring and responsible manner. The Authority's record over the years demonstrates its commitment to taking every reasonable effort to protect the environment, while continuing effective day-to-day operations of the Scheme. On-going consultations with relevant NSW agencies are a matter of course.

Although the existing arrangements for prior consultation with NSW agencies are seen as adequate, I have reinforced with the Authority the need to ensure this in relation to any future drainages of Guthega Reservoir.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health, upon notice, on 31 May 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Following my question without notice to the Minister on 24 May 1989 and his response (see Senate Hansard, page 2570), can the Minister provide the following information about the permits which were issued for 2 early shipments of spices which exceeded 600 becquerels per kilogram and were imported into Australia after the Chernobyl nuclear accident: (a) how, when and on what basis was the 600 becquerel per kilogram limit established; (b) when and on what basis were permits issued for the 2 shipments which exceeded the 600 becquerel limit; (c) a list of the items which were covered by these permits; (d) a list of the places of origin of the items covered by these permits; (e) a list of the arrival dates of these items into Australia, and (f) how, when and on what basis was it determined that these 2 shipments `did not present any health risk'.

(2) Can the Minister provide the following information about the 41 permits issued to cover items which exceeded 100 becquerels per kilogram and were imported into Australia after the Chernobyl nuclear accident: (a) how, when and on what basis was the 100 becquerel per kilogram limit established; (b) when and on what basis were 41 permits issued to cover items which exceeded the 100 becquerel limit; (c) a list of the items which were covered by these 41 permits; (d) a list of the places of origin of the items covered by the 41 permits; (e) list of the arrival dates of these items into Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Community Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) In September 1987, a limit value of 600 becquerels per kilogram was set, above which permits were not granted for the importation of foodstuffs into Australia. This is the same value as that adopted by many European countries as the limit for their domestically-consumed foodstuffs. It was known to be a conservative limit. In July 1988, the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organisation and the World Health Organization jointly recommended a guideline value of 1000 becquerels per kilogram for a diet in which all major foodstuffs are contaminated with caesium-137.

(b) The two shipments concerned were quantities of oregano and bay leaves from Turkey (permit number 16 and 21 in Table A). The quantities of the herbs in the two shipments were very small in relation to the total quantity consumed in Australia, virtually all of which remained free from radioactive contamination. The permission to import the two shipments was granted subject to the requirement that the oregano (or bay leaves) be diluted with other oregano (or bay leaves), or incorporated into manufactured products, such that the caesium-137 concentration in the foods made available for consumption by the public did not exceed 600 becquerels per kilogram. On this basis, it was deemed that the shipments would not present any hazard to health, as the added risk of fatal cancer for an individual eating the food would be less than one in ten million.

(2) (a) In July 1986, a caesium-137 concentration of 100 becquerels per kilogram was set, above which a permit to import was required. The value was not a limit; rather, it was a trigger point to make it possible to gauge the levels of radioactivity in foodstuffs entering the country. It served to highlight those types of foods where closer scrutiny might be desirable. Consumption of food at this level corresponds to a very low risk of radiation-induced cancer. Using the internationally accepted risk factors, it can be shown that the risk of contracting cancer following consumption of one kilogram of food containing 100 becquerels of caesium-137 is about one in fifty million. This would result in an insignificant increase in the present death-rate in Australia from cancer. (b) (c) (d) and (e) See Table A.
